title: ECON4538 - Syllabus
text:
Course Overview and Objectives
In this class we will address questions at the forefront of modern economic policy. What factors drive economic inequality over the life-cycle? How are these evolving over time? What are the potential costs and benefits to collective provision of insurance and redistribution? What policies are effective in creating equal opportunity?
To answer these questions you will learn the basic tools of modern quantitative economics. We will be interested in understanding the models and tools that economists have developed to understand labor market inequality, as well as in using these models to analyze the welfare implications of various government interventions. Topics to be covered include: dynamic programming, solution methods of general equilibrium models, heterogeneous-agent macroeconomic models, models of human capital formation, and modern empirical evidence on the nature human capital.

title: ECON4538 - Syllabus
text:
Student Learning Outcomes
On successfully completing this course, students should be familiar with some of the core concepts in modern quantitative economics. Students should be able to formalize an appropriate dynamic, stochastic, general equilibrium model to analyze a question of interest. Students should be able to solve and simulate such a model on a computer, for the purpose of interpreting data and conducting policy experiments.

title: ECON4538 - Syllabus
text:
Course Prerequisites
I will assume that you are comfortable with micro concepts at the level of Econ 3101, 3102, such as the utility maximization problem and its related topics. I will also assume that you are comfortable with basic econometrics such as multivariate regression techniques as well as statistics at the level of Stat 3011. With regards to your math background, I will take as granted that you know how to work with calculus (derivatives). Students should be willing to invest time in learning a computer programming language such as julia.

We will use some chapters and problem sets from Recursive Macroeconomic Theory (Ljungqvist and Sargent 2012, 3rd edition) available online via the University Library. Course Software and Resources
We will demonstrate and develop the computational tools you are learning using the julia programming language, which is well-suited for scientific computation and data analysis. LATIS provides a copy of julia on AppstoGo, but we recommend installing your own version, since it is completely free and open source. See the website for more details on the language and installation instructions.
Throughout the course, you may find the QuantEcon julia course (by Tom Sargent, John Stachurski, and Jesse Perla) a useful additional resource.

title: ECON4538 - Syllabus
text:
Course Outline

Dynamic Programming and Applications
An important set of mathematical tools for solving dynamic models. Topics include:

Bellman’s principal of optimality and contraction mappings
Mathematical and computational exposition (using julia) of dynamic programming tools, applied to:

Models of job search
Infinite horizon and life-cycle models of savings


Reading: Ljungqvist and Sargent (2012) Chapters 3-6.


Savings and incomplete markets
Review of the main theoretical models describing savings and self-insurance of agents under uncertainity and incomplete markets.

Main savings problems
Incomplete markets models as Huggett (1993), Aiyagari (1994), Krusell and Smith (1998)
Consumption inequality and income uncertainity.

Reading: Ljungqvist and Sargent (2012) Chapters 17-18. Deaton (1991), Blundell and Preston (1998), Huggett (1993), Aiyagari (1994), Krusell and Smith (1998)


Facts about Inequality
We review and replicate facts about labor market inequality in the United States. Topics include:

Documenting income inequality (Moffitt and Gottschalk 2011; Heathcote, Perri, and Violante 2010; Heathcote et al. 2023; Guvenen et al. 2021)
Estimation of income risk (Moffitt and Gottschalk 2011; Meghir and Pistaferri 2004; Low, Meghir, and Pistaferri 2010; Guvenen 2009)
Welfare implications of income inequality (Storesletten, Telmer, and Yaron 2004)

Redistribution vs Insurance

The Intergenerational Elasticity of Earnings (Corak 2013; Mazumder 2005, 2018)



Theories of Human Capital and Inequality
We introduce textbook theories of human capital formation and examine their empirical content. We develop computational tools to bring these theories to data. Topics include:

The Becker-Tomes model of intergenerational inequality via human capital investment (Becker and Tomes 1979, 1986)

Policy implications of the model (efficiency and redistribution)

Debates on the empirical and conceptual merits of the Becker-Tomes model (Goldberger 1989; Mulligan 1999; Cunha et al. 2006; Cunha and Heckman 2007)
Skills and Inequality (J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua 2006; Cunha and Heckman 2008a; Cunha and Heckman 2009)
Quantitative and theoretical extensions of the baseline model (Lee and Seshadri 2019; Caucutt and Lochner 2020)



Connecting Human Capital Theory with Evidence
We survey some empirical work that connects the theory with data. Topics include:

A review of econometric methods for causal inference
Evidence of the effect of social programs on child skill formation and long-run outcomes (Dahl and Lochner 2012; Barr, Eggleston, and Smith 2022; Bastian and Michelmore 2018; Carneiro et al. 2021; Bailey et al. 2024)
Evidence of the effect of early childhood education on skill formation and long-run outcomes (J. J. Heckman et al. 2010; García et al. 2020; Kline and Walters 2016)
Evidence of the effect of parenting and home interventions on skill formation and long-run outcomes (Attanasio, Meghir, and Nix 2020; Walker et al. 2022; Carneiro et al. 2024)
Estimating the technology of skill formation. (Cunha and Heckman 2008b; Attanasio, Meghir, and Nix 2020)

section: Key Finding 3: The Declining Role of the Household
text:
Key Finding 3: The Declining Role of the Household


Define index of household income pooling: \[ HP_{t} = \left(var(y_{it}) - var(\bar{y}_{it})\right) / var(y_{it}) \]
\(\bar{y}_{i}\): per-person income in household \(i\)
Interpretation: the share of variance in income reduced by pooling at household level
Household income pooling used to reduce inequality by 60% in 1967
By 2021, only reduces inequality by 35%
Why the decline? (decomposition exercise at board)

Narrowing gender earnings gap → women less reliant on spousal income
Rising correlation of earnings within couples → less insurance

Single households increasingly disadvantaged

Income and consumption inequality (Heathcote et al. 2023)

Key Finding 6: Wealth Amplifies Inequality


Wealth inequality has grown significantly since 1990s
Top 10% wealth share: ~65% in late 1980s → ~75% by 2019
Asymmetric pattern:

Below median: wealth ratios similar to income ratios
Above median: wealth ratios much larger and growing faster

Top households accumulate wealth faster than income grows

Main Takeaways from Heathcote et al. (2023)


Inequality at top: Driven by wage differentials, continues to grow (but more slowly)
Inequality at bottom: Driven by employment, dominated by cyclical fluctuations
The household: Declining importance as inequality-reducing mechanism
The government: Increasing role in redistribution and stabilization
Consumption: Remains remarkably stable despite income inequality trends

title: Documenting Inequality

Policy Implications


Labor market policies matter differently across distribution:

Top: Focus on wage-setting, skills, technology
Bottom: Focus on employment, labor force participation

Government transfers are increasingly important for:

Reducing long-run inequality
Stabilizing incomes during recessions (especially at bottom)

Marriage/family policies less effective as earnings correlate more within couples
Consumption smoothing: Households appear to insure well despite income volatility

text:
In this recitation we’re going to work with extracts of the CPS-ASEC from the years (1970,1980,1990,2000,2010,2019). This is a slightly smaller dataset than the version I’m using in class, but will nonetheless capture the same trends.
Our focus in this class will be earned income at the individual and household level, as well as government transfers at the individual and household level. The code below loads the data and creates some variables:

EARN which will be the sum of wages and business income
GOV which will be the sum of welfare, social security income, supplemental security income, the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) and the Child Tax Credit (CTC).

Some other things to note:

These are limited measures of income and if you peruse the variables in IPUMS you will find many more categories.
Wage and business income is subject to top coding and we are not doing anything to solve that issue here, but you should be aware of it. See Heathcote et al. (2023) for one approach to this problem.
Many of the variables we are analyzing are assigned dummy values (e.g. 9999999) if they are missing or not asked for an individual in the survey (“Not in Universe”). One should normally check to make sure these dummy values don’t appear in the final data.
Our measure of transfers does not include in-kind transfers such as Medicaid and Food Stamps (which comprise a very large share of overall transfers).

With that being said, below is code to load the data and create these variables:

using DataFrames, CSV, StatsPlots, DataFramesMeta, StatsBase

data = @chain CSV.read("../data/asec_1970_2019.csv",DataFrame) begin

    # fill in some missing values and deflat

    :SSI = 100 * coalesce.(:INCSSI,0.) ./ :PCE
    :WELF = 100 * :INCWELFR ./ :PCE
    :SS = 100 * :INCSS ./ :PCE
    # create the income measures
    :EARN = 100 * (:INCWAGE .+ :INCBUS) ./ :PCE #<- deflate earnings (2017 base)
    end
    @transform :GOV = :EITC .+ :CTC .+ :SSI .+ :WELF .+ :SS
end

How prominently do government transfers feature in the household budget constraint? And how has this evolved over time? Although our measures of income and transfers are not exhaustive, we can use them to get a partial answer to this question.
The code below calculates average transfers relative to average net income for the poorest 20% of households (as measured by our variable EARN) and produces a plot.

@chain house begin
    groupby(:YEAR)
    @transform :q20 = quantile(:EARN,0.2) #<- keep bottom 20% in each year
    @subset :EARN .< :q20
    groupby(:YEAR)
    @combine begin 
        :gov_share = mean(:GOV)  / (mean(:GOV) .+ mean(:EARN))
    end
    @df _ begin 
        plot(:YEAR,:gov_share,linewidth=3)
        scatter!(:YEAR,:gov_share,legend=false)
    end
end

    end
    stack(Not(:YEAR))
    @df _ plot(:YEAR,:value,group = :variable,linewidth = 3.)
end

title: Recitation 2
text:
Model
Let’s assume that individuals live for \(T\) periods. They face an income process that follows:
\[ \log(y_{it}) = \mu_{t} + \varepsilon_{it} \]
where
\[ \varepsilon_{it} = \rho \varepsilon_{it-1} + \zeta_{it},\ \zeta_{it} \sim \mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^2_{\zeta}).\]
We assume a single risk-free asset with a rate of return \(r\), so that the model can be phrased recursively:
\[ V_{t}(a,y) = \max_{a^\prime}\left\{u(y + a - (1+r)^{-1}a^\prime) + \beta \mathbb{E}_{y'}V_{t+1}(a',y') \right\} \]
with \(V_{T}=0\).
We assume that utility \(u\) is of the CRRA type, so we can write the function as:

utility(c,σ) = c^(1 - σ) / (1 - σ)

utility (generic function with 1 method)


Note that \(\mu_{t}\) is the mean of log income and can evolve with the age \(t\) of the agent, but this life-cycle profile in wages is known. \(\varepsilon\) is the unknown component of income and the source of risk in the model.

title: Recitation 2
text:
Solving the Model
This model can be solved almost identically to the infinite horizon version. We can start by writing a function to solve the maximization problem given a point in the asset and income grid.

function solve_value(ai,yi,V,p,t)
    (;σ,β,Π,r,asset_grid,income_grid) = p
    a = asset_grid[ai]
    y = exp(income_grid[yi,t])
    vmax = -Inf
    amax = 0
    for ai_next in eachindex(asset_grid)
        a_next = asset_grid[ai_next]
        c = y + a - a_next/(1+r)
        if c>0
            @views v = utility(c,σ) + β*dot(Π[:,yi],V[:,ai_next,t+1])
            if v>vmax
                vmax = v
                amax = a_next
            end
        end
    end
    return vmax,amax
end

solve_value (generic function with 1 method)


With this function in hand we can then write a function to iterate over each grid point and calculate \(V_{t}\) given \(V_{t+1}\):

function iterate_value_function!(p,V,A,t)
    for ai in axes(V,2), yi in axes(V,1)
        v,a_next = solve_value(ai,yi,V,p,t)
        V[yi,ai,t] = v
        A[yi,ai,t] = a_next
    end
end

iterate_value_function! (generic function with 1 method)


And finally we can solve the model by doing backward induction from \(T\) down to the first period.

function solve_model(p)
    (;T,Π,asset_grid) = p
    K_a = length(asset_grid)
    K_y = size(Π,1)
    V = zeros(K_y,K_a,T+1)
    A = zeros(K_y,K_a,T)
    for t in reverse(1:T)
        iterate_value_function!(p,V,A,t)
    end
    return (;V,A)
end

title: Recitation 2
text:
Approximating the income process
There are a number of methods for approximating the AR(1) process for income outlined above using a discrete state Markov process. A popular version is Tauchen’s method. The code below is a function to produce a transition matrix \(\Pi\) and a grid of values that approximates the variance and autocovariance of an AR(1) process.

using Distributions

function tauchen(N, ρ, σ)
    # Unconditional standard deviation of the process
    σ_y = σ / sqrt(1 - ρ^2)

    # Create the grid
    y_max = 3. * σ_y
    y_min = - 3. * σ_y
    grid = range(y_min, y_max, length=N)

    # Step size
    step = (y_max - y_min) / (N - 1)

    # Initialize transition matrix
    Π = zeros(N, N)

    # Standard normal distribution
    d = Normal(0, 1)

    # Fill in the transition matrix
    for i in 1:N
        for j in 1:N
            if j == 1
                # Probability of transitioning to the lowest state
                Π[j, i] = cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] + step/2) / σ)
            elseif j == N
                # Probability of transitioning to the highest state
                Π[j, i] = 1 - cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] - step/2) / σ)
            else
                # Probability of transitioning to intermediate states
                Π[j, i] = cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] + step/2) / σ) -
                         cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] - step/2) / σ)
            end
        end
    end
    return collect(grid), Π
end

This is going to produce a matrix where \(\Pi[j,i]\) contains the probability of moving to state \(j\) when currently in state \(i\).

Consumption equivalents
The welfare comparisons above are in arbitrary units. How can we convert them to something interpretable? One option is to think about a consumption equivalent: the percentage increase in consumption that someone would be willing to take to move from one regime to another. For example, given an initial income level, \(y\), the consumption equivalent here would solve:
\[ \mathbb{E}[\sum_{t=0}^{T}\beta^{t}u((1+\omega(y))c_{t}) | y, \rho = 0.9] = \mathbb{E}[\sum_{t=0}^{T}\beta^{t}u(c_{t}) | y, \rho = 0.45] \]
which solves out to:
\[ \omega(y) = \left[\frac{V_{0}(0,y ; \rho = 0.45)}{V_{0}(0,y ; \rho = 0.9)}\right]^{1/(1-\sigma)} - 1 \]
Let’s calculate and plot this for each income level:

title: Recitation 3

Setup
Let there be a unit measure of agents in the economy, indexed by \(i\in[0,1]\). As before, assume that agents rank probabilistic sequences of consumption according to:
\[ V^{r}_{i} = \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\beta^{t}u(c^{r}_{i,t})\right]\]
where \(\{c^{r}_{i,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1}\) is the sequence of consumption that agent \(i\) enjoys under regime \(r\in\{A,B\}\).
Let \(\bar{c}^{r}_{i}\) be the certainty equivalent that solves: \[ \sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\beta^{t}u(\bar{c}^{r}_{i}) = V^{r}_{i}\] for \(r\in\{A,B\}\). We know that: \[\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}u(\bar{c}^{r}_{i}) = \frac{(1-\beta^{T})}{1-\beta}\beta^{t}u(\bar{c}^{r}_{i}) = \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{r}_{i})\] Finally, define \(C=\int y_{i,t}di = \int c_{i,t}di\) as aggregate or average consumption in the economy. In both regimes we assume that the resource constraint always holds and there is no aggregate uncertainty. Just as in our lecture, we can define the aggregate certainty equivalent as: \[ \bar{C}^{r} = \int \bar{c}^{r}_{i}di.\]
Note that by definition, we have: \[ W^{r} = \int V^{r}_{i}di = \int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{r}_{i})di \]

In both regimes we assume that the resource constraint always holds and there is no aggregate uncertainty. Just as in our lecture, we can define the aggregate certainty equivalent as: \[ \bar{C}^{r} = \int \bar{c}^{r}_{i}di.\]
Note that by definition, we have: \[ W^{r} = \int V^{r}_{i}di = \int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{r}_{i})di \]

title: Recitation 3
text:
The decomposition
Note that now we can write:
\[ W^{r} = \mathcal{V}(C^{r}) \times \frac{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{r})}{\mathcal{V}(C^{r})} \times \frac{\int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{r}_{i})di}{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{r})}\] The first term here is the value obtained if we implemented perfect insurance (everyone gets the same consumption in all periods). The second term is the discount on this perfect insurance when everyone is given the average certainty equivalent, and the third term is the further discount coming from inequality in the allocations of certainty equivalents. You can think of the second and third terms as being “costs” relative to a benchmark. The second term is the cost of imperfect insurance in the model relative to a “perfect insurance” benchmark. The third term is the cost of inequality, stemming from differences in individual certainty equivalent values. Welfare is therefore the product of an aggregate component, an insurance component, and a redistribution component.
Since aggregate income and consumption are unchanged by the policies we consider, the first term cancels out when we decompose the welfare changes when moving from regime \(A\) to regime \(B\) as:
\[ \frac{W^{B}}{W^{A}} = \frac{\frac{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{B})}{\mathcal{V}(C^{B})}}{\frac{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}{\mathcal{V}(C^{A})}} \times \frac{\frac{\int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{A}_{i})di}{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}}{\frac{\int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{A}_{i})di}{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}}  \]
We can convert these terms into consumption equivalent measures using the formula from recitation 2: \[
\begin{eqnarray}
1 + \omega = \left[\frac{W^{B}}{W^{A}}\right]^{1/(1-\sigma)} \\
1+\gamma = \left[\frac{\frac{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{B})}{\mathcal{V}(C^{B})}}{\frac{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}{\mathcal{V}(C^{A})}}\right]^{1/(1-\sigma)} \\
1 + \alpha = \left[\frac{\frac{\int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{A}_{i})di}{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}}{\frac{\int \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}^{A}_{i})di}{\mathcal{V}(\bar{C}^{A})}}\right]^{1/(1-\sigma)}
\end{eqnarray}
\] with \(1+\omega = (1+\gamma)(1+\alpha)\) being the final decomposition.
The \(\gamma\) term here is the welfare effect of changes in insurance, the \(\alpha\) term represents changes in the equality (or inequality) of the distribution of certainty equivalents.

title: Income Processes
text:
A Canonical Decomposition
Following Meghir and Pistaferri (2004), decompose log earnings \(y_{it}\):
\[y_{it} = m_t^e + \beta^e Z_{it} + u_{it}\]
where:


\(m_t^e\): calendar year effects (education-specific)
\(Z_{it}\): observables (age, race, region, etc.)
\(u_{it}\): stochastic component (our focus today)

title: Income Processes
text:
Decomposing the Stochastic Component
The residual \(u_{it}\) has three parts:
\[u_{it} = r_{it} + e_{it} + p_{it}\]


\(r_{it}\): i.i.d. measurement error
\(e_{it}\): transitory shock (serially correlated)
\(p_{it}\): permanent component (random walk)

title: Income Processes
text:
The Permanent Component
Permanent component follows a random walk:
\[p_{it} = p_{it-1} + \zeta_{it}\]


\(\zeta_{it}\): permanent innovation (martingale difference sequence)
Examples: job loss, promotion, health shocks, skill depreciation
Key implication: shocks have permanent effects on earnings level
Contrast with transitory shocks that mean-revert

title: Income Processes
text:
The Transitory Component
Transitory shock follows MA(q) process:
\[e_{it} = \varepsilon_{it} - \theta_1^e \varepsilon_{it-1} - \cdots - \theta_q^e \varepsilon_{it-q}\]


\(\varepsilon_{it}\): transitory innovation
Examples: overtime, bonuses, temporary layoffs
Persistence captured by MA parameters
Order \(q\) determined empirically

title: Income Processes
text:
First Differences
Taking first differences eliminates fixed effects:
\[g_{it} = \Delta y_{it} = \Delta m_t^e + \beta^e \Delta Z_{it} + \Delta u_{it}\]
\[g_{it} = \Delta r_{it} + \Delta e_{it} + \zeta_{it}\]
This is a composite MA(q+1) process in the innovations.

title: Income Processes
text:
Testing the Income Process Model
Meghir and Pistaferri (2004) use autocovariances of earnings growth to:


Determine order \(q\) of MA process for transitory shocks
Test for presence of permanent shocks (is \(\text{var}(\zeta) = 0\)?)
Estimate unconditional variances of permanent and transitory components
Model conditional variance (ARCH effects)

title: Income Processes
text:
Key Identification Result
For MA(q) transitory shocks, earnings growth satisfies:
\[E(g_{it} g_{it-j}) = 0 \text{ for } j > q+1\]


This allows testing order of MA process
Also provides moment conditions to identify variance of permanent shock
Key insight: permanent and transitory shocks have different autocorrelation signatures

Three unknowns, two equations:


Cannot separately identify: \(\text{var}(\varepsilon)\), \(\text{var}(r)\), and \(\theta\)
Two approaches:

Bound the unidentified parameters
Use external estimate of measurement error variance

Meghir and Pistaferri (2004) do both

title: Income Processes
text:
What is a Stochastic Process?
A stochastic process describes how a variable evolves randomly over time.
For earnings, we might write: \[y_{it} = f(y_{it-1}, y_{it-2}, \ldots, \varepsilon_{it})\]


\(y_{it}\): person \(i\)’s log earnings at time \(t\)
\(\varepsilon_{it}\): random shock (the “new news” at time \(t\))
Different processes = different ways shocks affect future earnings

title: Income Processes
text:
White Noise (i.i.d. Process)
The simplest process: white noise
\[y_{it} = \varepsilon_{it}\]
where \(\varepsilon_{it} \sim\) i.i.d. \(N(0, \sigma^2)\)


Each period is independent of the past
Shocks have no persistence
Example: random measurement error
Not realistic for earnings (last year’s income predicts this year’s)

title: Income Processes
text:
Random Walk Process
A random walk accumulates all past shocks:
\[y_{it} = y_{it-1} + \varepsilon_{it}\]
Expanding backward: \(y_{it} = y_{i0} + \sum_{s=1}^t \varepsilon_{is}\)


Today’s value = yesterday’s value + new shock
Shocks are permanent (never fade)
Variance grows over time: \(\text{var}(y_{it}) = t\sigma^2\)
Example: stock prices, permanent disability

title: Income Processes
text:
Comparing Random Walk vs AR(1)


Random Walk

Shocks permanent
Variance grows: \(t\sigma^2\)
No mean reversion
Paths diverge


AR(1)

Shocks fade
Variance converges
Mean reversion
Paths stabilize


Key question for earnings: Which better describes reality?

title: Income Processes
text:
MA(1) Process
A moving average process uses lagged shocks:
\[y_{it} = \varepsilon_{it} + \theta \varepsilon_{it-1}\]


Shock affects current period AND next period
After that, completely forgotten
Example: multi-period bonus, temporary layoff
\(\theta > 0\): positive shock today → higher earnings next year too
\(\theta < 0\): positive shock today → lower earnings next year (compensation/smoothing)

title: Income Processes
text:
MA(1) vs AR(1): Key Difference
AR(1): persistence in the level

High earnings today → high earnings tomorrow
Effect fades gradually

MA(1): persistence in the shock

Shock today → affects next period
Then completely forgotten

For earnings growth \(g_{it} = \Delta y_{it}\), MA(1) creates correlation between \(g_{it}\) and \(g_{it-1}\), but \(g_{it}\) and \(g_{it-2}\) are uncorrelated!

title: Income Processes
text:
Why This Matters for Earnings
Different processes → different implications:


Random walk: job loss permanently lowers earnings
AR(1): earnings shocks fade over time
MA(1): shocks have short-term persistence
More persistent shocks are harder to self-insure against. Insurance more valuable.



Key question: Which process(es) best describe earnings data?

Overview

Today: how does economic status persist across generations?
Key questions:

How strong is the link between parent and child earnings?
Does the U.S. have more or less mobility than other countries?

Building up to a theory of intergenerational inequality

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
The American Dream
A central tenet of American identity:

“Each generation should do better than the last, regardless of where they start”



Does this hold empirically?
How much does your parent’s income determine yours?
Is the U.S. “the land of opportunity”?

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Why Study Intergenerational Mobility?


Normative: Many view high mobility as desirable

Equal opportunity vs equal outcomes

Positive: Understanding persistence of inequality

Will income disparities persist or fade?

Policy: Identifying effective interventions

Education? Early childhood? Neighborhoods?

Theory: Testing models of human capital accumulation

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Connection to Income Processes
Recall from Lecture 3:
\[y_{it} = \alpha_i + \beta_i \cdot t + p_{it} + e_{it}\]


\(\alpha_i\): permanent individual component
Where does \(\alpha_i\) come from?
One answer: parental resources, investments
Mobility studies: correlation between parent and child \(\alpha\)’s

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
The Intergenerational Elasticity (IGE)
Most common measure: regression of child log income on parent log income
\[y_{\text{child}, i} = \alpha + \beta \cdot y_{\text{parent}, i} + \varepsilon_i\]


\(\beta\) = intergenerational elasticity (IGE)
\(\beta = 0\): no relationship (perfect mobility)
\(\beta = 1\): perfect persistence (no mobility)
Typical estimates: \(\beta \approx 0.4\) to 0.6

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Interpreting the IGE
If \(\beta = 0.5\):


Child of parent earning 50% more � expects to earn 25% more
Gap shrinks by 50% each generation
But: takes many generations to converge
Example: $100K vs $50K difference

Generation 1: $50K gap
Generation 2: $25K gap
Generation 3: $12.5K gap

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Alternative Measure: Rank-Rank Slope
Chetty et al. (2014) popularized rank-based measures:
\[\text{rank}_{\text{child}, i} = \alpha + \beta_r \cdot \text{rank}_{\text{parent}, i} + \varepsilon_i\]


Ranks: 0-100 percentile in income distribution
\(\beta_r\): how much does parent rank predict child rank?

text:
Rank-Rank: Interpretation
If \(\beta_r = 0.3\):


Child of 25th percentile parent expects to reach 33rd percentile
Child of 75th percentile parent expects to reach 58th percentile
Movement toward middle: mean reversion
But substantial persistence remains

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Absolute vs Relative Mobility
Two distinct concepts:


Relative mobility: your rank compared to parents (what we’ve discussed)
Absolute mobility: do you earn more than your parents did?



Key insight: Can have high absolute mobility (everyone richer) with low relative mobility (ranks unchanged)

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Measurement Error Attenuation
Classical measurement error biases IGE toward zero:
\[y_{\text{parent}}^{\text{observed}} = y_{\text{parent}}^{\text{true}} + \nu\]
True model: \(y_{\text{child}} = \alpha + \beta \cdot y_{\text{parent}}^{\text{true}} + \varepsilon\)
But we estimate: \(y_{\text{child}} = \alpha + \beta^* \cdot y_{\text{parent}}^{\text{observed}} + \varepsilon^*\)


Result: \(\beta^* < \beta\) (attenuation bias)
Solution: Average parent income over many years
Or use instrumental variables

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Linking to Becker-Tomes Model
Simple framework (Becker and Tomes 1979):
\[y_{\text{child}} = h(I_{\text{parent}}, \theta, \varepsilon)\]


\(I\): parental investments (money, time)
\(\theta\): child ability/endowment
\(\varepsilon\): luck/environment
Parents choose \(I\) to maximize child outcomes
Predicts: IGE depends on returns to investment

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
What Determines the IGE?
In Becker-Tomes framework:
\[\beta = \frac{\text{var}(I) \cdot \left(\frac{\partial y}{\partial I}\right)^2 + \text{cov}(\theta, y_{\text{parent}})}{\text{var}(y_{\text{parent}})}\]


Higher return to investment \(\rightarrow\) higher IGE
More inequality in investments \(\rightarrow\) higher IGE
More inequality in endowments \(\rightarrow\) potentially lower IGE
Connection to income processes: investments affect \(\alpha_i\)

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Credit Constraints
If poor families are credit constrained:


Cannot invest optimally in children
Creates persistence: poor � low investment � poor
Rich families invest more efficiently
Implication: IGE could be lowered by:

Education subsidies
Early childhood programs
Reducing borrowing constraints




We’ll explore these policies in later lectures.

Genetic vs environmental transmission:


Genetic: ability, personality traits
Environmental: investments, culture, neighborhoods
Evidence: adoption studies show both matter
But: gene-environment interactions complicate story
Policy can’t change genes, but can change returns to ability

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
The Equity-Efficiency Tradeoff?
Traditional view: redistribution reduces efficiency
But: if mobility is low due to market failures:


Credit constraints � underinvestment in poor children
This is inefficient (high-return investments not made)
Policies that increase mobility may increase efficiency
Depends on whether low mobility reflects optimal responses or constraints

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
The Role of Place-Based Policies
Evidence suggests where you grow up matters:


Move to better neighborhood � better outcomes
But: neighborhood characteristics are endogenous
Place-based policies:

Promise zones, empowerment zones
School improvements
Infrastructure investments

Key question: cheaper to move people or improve places?

title: Intergenerational Mobility
text:
Universal vs Targeted Programs
Two approaches:


Universal: benefits for all children (e.g., public schools)

Pros: less stigma, political support
Cons: expensive, some waste

Targeted: focus on disadvantaged (e.g., Head Start)

Pros: cost-effective, high returns
Cons: potential stigma, targeting challenges

Who stays in their birth location?


Successful children may leave low-mobility areas

Unsuccessful children may return to low-cost areas

U.S. has lower mobility than many developed countries (\(\beta \approx 0.4-0.6\))

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Overview


Previous lecture: geographic variation in mobility
Today: theory of intergenerational transmission
The Becker-Tomes model (Becker and Tomes 1979, 1986)
Key questions:

Why do earnings regress to the mean?
How do parents affect children’s outcomes?
What determines the speed of mobility?

Building a unified framework for inequality and mobility

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Three Channels of Transmission
Parents affect children through:


Endowments (genes and culture): \(E_t\)

IQ, personality, work ethic, cultural capital

Human capital investments: \(x_t\)

Education, training, health, early childhood

Financial transfers: bequests and gifts

Assets, property, cash transfers




Each channel has different properties for transmission across generations.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Endowment Transmission
Endowments follow a Markov process:
\[E_t = \alpha + h E_{t-1} + v_t\]


\(h\) = inheritability parameter (how much is passed on)
\(0 < h < 1\): endowments regress to the mean
\(\alpha\) = social endowment (common to all)
\(v_t\) = random luck in endowment transmission



Think: What does \(h < 1\) imply for children of high-ability parents?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Why Does h < 1?


Genetics: Mendel’s laws → regression to the mean

Child gets random draw from parents’ genes
Extreme traits don’t fully transmit

Culture: imperfect transmission of values/habits

Peer effects, media, broader environment matter

Empirical evidence: \(h \approx 0.3\) to \(0.6\) for earnings-relevant traits



This automatic regression is key to understanding mobility.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Generation
Adult earnings depend on human capital and luck:
\[Y_t = H_t + \varepsilon_t\]
where human capital is produced by:
\[H_t = \psi(x_{t-1}, s_{t-1}, E_t)\]


\(x_{t-1}\) = parental investments
\(s_{t-1}\) = public investments (schools, etc.)
\(E_t\) = endowments
\(\psi\) is increasing in all three inputs

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Complementarity
Key assumption: endowments and investments are complements
\[\frac{\partial^2 H_t}{\partial x_{t-1} \partial E_t} > 0\]


Higher ability → higher return to education
Better endowed children get more from investments
Reinforces initial advantages
Creates skewness in earnings distribution



Question: Does this match your intuition about returns to education?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Wealth-Maximizing Case
Suppose parents can borrow freely against children’s future earnings.
Then they solve: \[\max_{x_{t-1}} \quad H_t(x_{t-1}, E_t) - (1+r) x_{t-1}\]
First-order condition: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} = 1 + r\]

Implication: Marginal return on human capital = interest rate for ALL families.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Investment with Perfect Markets





  
    
  



  
    
  



  
    
  






































Higher endowment → higher optimal investment (even at same r).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings with Perfect Markets
Substitute optimal \(x^*\) into earnings:
\[Y_t = H_t(x^*(E_t), E_t) + \varepsilon_t = \phi(E_t, r) + \varepsilon_t\]
Replace \(E_t\) using the Markov process:
\[Y_t = c_t + h \cdot Y_{t-1} + \text{error terms}\]


Key result: earnings regress at rate \(1-h\)
Speed of regression = inheritability of endowments
No direct effect of parents’ income (perfect credit markets!)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Consumption and Bequests
With perfect markets, parents choose bequests to satisfy:
\[u'(Z_t) = \delta (1+r) u'(Z_{t+1})\]


If \(\delta(1+r) = 1\): consumption growth = 0
Consumption does not regress to mean!
Parents use bequests to offset earnings regression
Rich parents leave large bequests to maintain consumption



Surprising: Perfect mobility in earnings, but dynasties persist in consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Realistic Case
Most families cannot borrow against children’s future earnings.


Human capital is poor collateral
Moral hazard: children can shirk
Legal restrictions: can’t obligate children for parents’ debt



Implication: Parents must self-finance investments in children.
Now parents’ income matters for investments!

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Constrained Optimization
Parents without assets must trade off:

Own consumption \(Z_t\)
Investment in children \(x_{t-1}\)

This means: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} > 1 + r\]

Marginal return on human capital exceeds interest rate for poor families.
Why? Reducing \(x\) raises marginal utility of parents’ consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Investment with Capital Constraints





Poorer families invest less due to higher marginal cost of funds.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Regression with Constraints
Now earnings depend on both endowments AND parents’ income:
\[Y_t = \phi(E_t, Y_{t-1}, s_{t-1})\]


\(\frac{\partial Y_t}{\partial Y_{t-1}} = \beta^* > 0\) (income effect)
Richer parents invest more in children
Creates additional persistence beyond \(h\)
Two-generation regression equation:


\[Y_t \approx c_t + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \text{errors}\]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Three-Generation Test
The model predicts:

Positive coefficient on parents’ earnings: \(\beta^* + h\)
Negative coefficient on grandparents’ earnings: \(-\beta^* h\)



Grandparents matter through their effect on parents
But holding parents’ earnings fixed, rich grandparents ↔︎ rich parents ↔︎ lower investments needed
This negative coefficient is testable!
Evidence (limited): Wahl (1985) finds negative coefficient

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Efficiency Loss from Constraints
Capital constraints cause inefficiency:


Marginal return is higher in poor families
But they invest less
Redistributing investment from rich → poor would raise total output
Equity and efficiency both favor helping poor families
Justifies subsidies to education for disadvantaged children



Policy implication: Progressive education funding can be efficiency-enhancing.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Public Investments
How do public expenditures \(s_t\) affect the system?


If perfect substitutes for \(x_t\): partial crowd-out

Rich families reduce \(x_t\) dollar-for-dollar
Poor families reduce less (still constrained)

If complements (e.g., subsidize tuition → raises return to parental time):

Can increase total investment
Substitution effect works against redistribution effect




Evidence: Many programs show weak effects due to family offsetting behavior.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Fertility
Allow number of children \(n_t\) to vary:
\[U_t = u(Z_t) + \alpha(n_t) n_t U_{t+1}\]
with \(\alpha'(n_t) < 0\) (diminishing marginal utility of children).


Richer families have more children
This dilutes bequests per child
Induces regression in wealth per child
Helps explain why dynasties don’t persist forever

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Marriage
Assortative mating: tendency to marry someone similar.


Positive correlation in spouses’ endowments
But imperfect: \(\text{corr}(E_{\text{mother}}, E_{\text{father}}) < 1\)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
We have learned that income inequality tends to persist across generations
Today: theory of intergenerational transmission
The Becker-Tomes model (Becker and Tomes 1979, 1986) is a workhorse framework
We’ll study some stylized versions
Key questions:

Why do earnings regress to the mean?
How do parents affect children’s outcomes?
What determines the speed of mobility?

Building a unified framework for inequality and mobility

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Three Channels of Transmission
Parents affect children through:


Endowments (genes and culture): \(E_t\)

IQ, personality, work ethic, cultural capital

Human capital investments: \(x_t\)

Education, training, health, early childhood

Financial transfers: bequests and gifts

Assets, property, cash transfers




Each channel has different properties for transmission across generations.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Endowment Transmission
Endowments follow a Markov process:
\[E_t = \alpha + h E_{t-1} + v_t\]


\(h\) = inheritability parameter (how much is passed on)
\(0 < h < 1\): endowments regress to the mean
\(\alpha\) = social endowment (common to all)
\(v_t\) = random luck in endowment transmission



Think: What does \(h < 1\) imply for children of high-ability parents?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Why Does h < 1?


Genetics: Mendel’s laws → regression to the mean

Child gets random draw from parents’ genes
Extreme traits don’t fully transmit

Culture: imperfect transmission of values/habits

Peer effects, media, broader environment matter

Empirical evidence: \(h \approx 0.3\) to \(0.6\) for earnings-relevant traits



This automatic regression is key to understanding mobility.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Generation
Adult earnings depend on human capital and luck:
\[Y_t = H_t + \varepsilon_t\]
where human capital is produced by:
\[H_t = \psi(x_{t-1}, s_{t-1}, E_t)\]


\(x_{t-1}\) = parental investments
\(s_{t-1}\) = public investments (schools, etc.)
\(E_t\) = endowments
\(\psi\) is increasing in all three inputs

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Complementarity
Key assumption: endowments and investments are complements
\[\frac{\partial^2 H_t}{\partial x_{t-1} \partial E_t} > 0\]


Higher ability → higher return to education
Better endowed children get more from investments
Reinforces initial advantages
Creates skewness in earnings distribution



Question: Does this match your intuition about returns to education?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Wealth-Maximizing Case
Suppose parents can borrow freely against children’s future earnings.
Then they solve: \[\max_{x_{t-1}} \quad H_t(x_{t-1}, E_t) - (1+r) x_{t-1}\]
First-order condition: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} = 1 + r\]

Implication: Marginal return on human capital = interest rate for ALL families.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model

Higher endowment → higher optimal investment (even at same r).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings with Perfect Markets
Substitute optimal \(x^*\) into earnings:
\[Y_t = H_t(x^*(E_t), E_t) + \varepsilon_t = \phi(E_t, r) + \varepsilon_t\]
Replace \(E_t\) using the Markov process:
\[Y_t = c_t + h \cdot Y_{t-1} + \text{error terms}\]


Key result: earnings regress at rate \(1-h\)
Speed of regression = inheritability of endowments
No direct effect of parents’ income (perfect credit markets!)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Consumption and Bequests
With perfect markets, parents choose bequests to satisfy:
\[u'(Z_t) = \delta (1+r) u'(Z_{t+1})\]


If \(\delta(1+r) = 1\): consumption growth = 0
Consumption does not regress to mean!
Parents use bequests to offset earnings regression
Rich parents leave large bequests to maintain consumption



Surprising: Perfect mobility in earnings, but dynasties persist in consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Realistic Case
Most families cannot borrow against children’s future earnings.


Human capital is poor collateral
Moral hazard: children can shirk
Legal restrictions: can’t obligate children for parents’ debt



Implication: Parents must self-finance investments in children.
Now parents’ income matters for investments!

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:

Parents without assets must trade off:

Own consumption \(Z_t\)
Investment in children \(x_{t-1}\)

This means: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} > 1 + r\]

Marginal return on human capital exceeds interest rate for poor families.
Why? Reducing \(x\) raises marginal utility of parents’ consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:

Poorer families invest less due to higher marginal cost of funds.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Regression with Constraints
Now earnings depend on both endowments AND parents’ income:
\[Y_t = \phi(E_t, Y_{t-1}, s_{t-1})\]


\(\frac{\partial Y_t}{\partial Y_{t-1}} = \beta^* > 0\) (income effect)
Richer parents invest more in children
Creates additional persistence beyond \(h\)
Two-generation regression equation:


\[Y_t \approx c_t + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \text{errors}\]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model

The model predicts:

Positive coefficient on parents’ earnings: \(\beta^* + h\)
Negative coefficient on grandparents’ earnings: \(-\beta^* h\)



Grandparents matter through their effect on parents
But holding parents’ earnings fixed, rich grandparents ↔︎ rich parents ↔︎ lower investments needed
This negative coefficient is testable!
Evidence (limited): Wahl (1985) finds negative coefficient

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:

Capital constraints cause inefficiency:


Marginal return is higher in poor families
But they invest less
Redistributing investment from rich → poor would raise total output
Equity and efficiency both favor helping poor families
Justifies subsidies to education for disadvantaged children



Policy implication: Progressive education funding can be efficiency-enhancing.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model

If perfect substitutes for \(x_t\): partial crowd-out

Rich families reduce \(x_t\) dollar-for-dollar
Poor families reduce less (still constrained)

If complements (e.g., subsidize tuition → raises return to parental time):

Can increase total investment
Substitution effect works against redistribution effect




Evidence: Many programs show weak effects due to family offsetting behavior.

This dilutes bequests per child

Helps explain why dynasties don’t persist forever

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Goldberger Critique
Goldberger (1989) raised a fundamental question:


Are Becker-Tomes predictions distinct from simple Galton model?
Galton: \(Y_t = \alpha + h Y_{t-1} + \varepsilon_t\) (just genetics)
Becker-Tomes adds: investments, capital markets, bequests
Question: Do these additions generate unique testable predictions?
Or do we just get the same regression-to-mean result?



This motivated systematic testing of unique Becker-Tomes implications.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Mulligan’s Empirical Tests
Mulligan (1999) tests 9 unique implications of Becker-Tomes vs. Galton:


Uses multiple datasets: PSID, NLS, SCF
Examines earnings, consumption, and wealth
Distinguishes families by transfer behavior
Result: Several key predictions fail empirically



Let’s examine the most important failures.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 1: Consumption Mobility
Becker-Tomes prediction: With perfect credit markets, consumption should not regress to mean among transfer-making families.

Rich parents use bequests to offset earnings regression
Dynasty persists in consumption even as earnings regress



Evidence (Mulligan (1999), Table 3): Consumption does regress!
Among families making transfers: \(\beta_{\text{consumption}} \approx 0.3\)
Similar to earnings regression
Suggests credit markets are NOT perfect even for rich families

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 2: Earnings Inequality
Becker-Tomes prediction: Families making transfers (unconstrained) should have more equal children’s earnings than constrained families.

Why? Unconstrained families equate marginal returns
Only endowment variation matters, not income variation
Constrained families: both endowments AND income matter



Evidence (Mulligan (1999), Table 6): Opposite pattern!
Children of transfer-making families have more earnings inequality
Suggests complementarity between parental resources and outcomes
Basic two-period model misses something important

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 3: The Grandparent Effect
Becker-Tomes prediction: Controlling for parents’ income, grandparents’ income should have negative effect.
\[Y_t \approx c_t + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \varepsilon_t\]


Intuition: Rich grandparents → rich parents → less investment needed
Evidence (Mulligan (1999)): Coefficient on \(Y_{t-2}\) is positive or zero
Not the predicted negative relationship
Suggests longer-run dynamics than two-generation model

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
What’s Missing?
The failures point to important omissions:


Multi-period structure: Investments span childhood, not one shot
Multiple skills: Cognitive and non-cognitive abilities matter
Dynamic complementarity: Early investments affect returns to later ones
Self-productivity: Skills today enhance skill formation tomorrow
Life-cycle timing: When investments occur matters



Solution: Extend to multi-period framework with richer technology.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Cunha-Heckman Technology
Cunha and Heckman (2007) develop a multi-stage model of skill formation:
\[\theta_{t+1} = f_t(h, \theta_t, I_t)\]


\(\theta_t\) = vector of skills at age \(t\) (cognitive, non-cognitive)
\(I_t\) = vector of investments at age \(t\) (parental, public)
\(h\) = child’s genetic endowment
\(f_t\) = age-specific production function



Key: Production function changes over development stages.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Two Key Properties
1. Self-Productivity
\[\frac{\partial \theta_{t+1}}{\partial \theta_t} > 0\]
Skills acquired in one period boost skill formation in the next period.


Learning-to-learn
Higher ability children accumulate skills faster
Creates compounding advantages
Explains why early gaps widen over time

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Two Key Properties (continued)
2. Dynamic Complementarity
\[\frac{\partial^2 \theta_{t+1}}{\partial I_t \partial \theta_t} > 0\]
Higher skill stocks raise the productivity of subsequent investments.


Investment is more productive for already-skilled children
Early investments raise returns to later investments
Creates path dependence
Different from static complementarity in basic model

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
A Simple Two-Period Example
Suppose skills evolve over two childhood periods:
\[\theta_1 = f_0(h, I_0)\] \[\theta_2 = f_1(h, \theta_1, I_1)\]
Adult earnings: \(Y = H(\theta_2) + \varepsilon\)


Early investment \(I_0\) affects \(\theta_1\) directly
But also affects productivity of \(I_1\) (dynamic complementarity)
And \(\theta_1\) affects \(\theta_2\) directly (self-productivity)
Total effect of \(I_0\) includes three channels

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
CES Specification
Cunha and Heckman (2007) use a CES production function:
\[\theta_{t+1} = \left[\gamma_1 \theta_t^\phi + \gamma_2 I_t^\phi\right]^{1/\phi}\]


\(\phi\) determines elasticity of substitution: \(\sigma = 1/(1-\phi)\)
\(\phi < 1\): Skills and investment are complements
\(\gamma_1, \gamma_2\): relative importance of self-productivity vs. investment
Can estimate separately for different ages and skill types



Empirical finding: \(\phi < 0\) for early childhood (strong complementarity).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Critical and Sensitive Periods
The multi-period framework allows for:


Critical periods: Times when \(\partial f_t / \partial I_t\) is especially high

Investment has large direct effect
Example: Language acquisition 0-3 years

Sensitive periods: Times when complementarity is strongest

Investment affects returns to all future investments
Example: Executive function development 3-5 years

Empirical evidence: Early childhood is both critical and sensitive

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Rationalizing the Evidence
The multi-period model addresses Mulligan’s critiques:


Consumption mobility: Multiple constraints over child’s development

Can’t borrow against future at each stage
Even rich families face some constraints

Earnings inequality: Dynamic complementarity reinforces advantages

Rich parents invest more at ALL stages
Complementarities amplify initial differences

Grandparent effects: Longer transmission chain

\(Y_{t-2}\) affects multiple periods of \(Y_{t-1}\)’s development
Positive persistence through multiple channels

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Policy Implications from Multi-Period Model
The timing of intervention matters:


Early investments have high returns

Affect all subsequent stages through complementarity
Self-productivity multiplies initial effects
Equity and efficiency align for early programs

Late remediation is costly

Must overcome accumulated deficits
Low complementarity with missing early skills
Equity-efficiency tradeoff emerges

Targeting matters

Complementarity → target disadvantaged children early
Universal programs may have low returns if constraints don’t bind

Cognitive and non-cognitive skills from test scores
Investments from time use and expenditures
Key findings:

Strong complementarity in early childhood (\(\phi < 0\))
Self-productivity dominates investment by adolescence
Optimal investment front-loaded to early ages
Explains fadeout of programs that don’t continue investing

# construct forward-lags

    d_lag = @chain d begin
        @select :person :year $var
        @transform :year = :year .- l
        @rename $(Symbol(var,"_",l)) = $var
    end
    d = leftjoin(d, d_lag, on=[:person,:year])
    return d
end

Now suppose that income in the model follows an AR(1) process:
\[ y_{it} = \mu_{t} + \varepsilon_{it} \]
where:
\[ \varepsilon_{t+1} = \rho \varepsilon_t + \zeta_{t+1}, \quad \zeta_{t+1} \sim N(0, \sigma^2_\zeta) \]
We can construct the residuals \(\varepsilon\) by first de-meaning by age. We take lags as well:

d = @chain d begin
    groupby(:age)
    @transform :eps = :logy .- mean(:logy)
end

d = forward_lag(d, 2, :eps);
d = forward_lag(d, 4, :eps);
d = forward_lag(d, 6, :eps);

Recall that:
\[ \text{Cov}(\varepsilon_t, \varepsilon_{t+s}) = \rho^{s}\text{Var}(\varepsilon_{t}).\]
This means that there are a multiple ways to estimate the persistence parameter \(\rho\), using different orders of lags.
There are also multiple ways to estimate \(\sigma^2_{\zeta}\). The simplest way is to assume that \(\varepsilon\) is in its stationary distribution which gives:
\[ \text{Var}(\varepsilon_{it}) = \sigma^2_{\zeta} / (1 - \rho^2) .\]
Below is code to calculate the covariance at different lags and estimate \(\rho\) as the mean of three alternative estimators.

cov_lag = pairwise(cov, eachcol(d[!,[:eps,:eps_2,:eps_4,:eps_6]]),
                    skipmissing = :pairwise)[:,1]


# Estimate ρ from the ratio of covariances at different lags
ρ_est_1 = sqrt(cov_lag[2] / cov_lag[1])  # (Cov(t,t+2) / Var(t))^(1/2)
ρ_est_2 = (cov_lag[3] / cov_lag[1])^(1/4)  # (Cov(t,t+4) / Var(t))^(1/4)
ρ_est_3 = (cov_lag[4] / cov_lag[1])^(1/6)  # (Cov(t,t+6) / Var(t))^(1/6)

ρ = mean([ρ_est_1, ρ_est_2, ρ_est_3])

println("Estimated persistence: ρ = ", round(ρ, digits=3))

# Given ρ, we can back out the innovation variance
σ_ε = sqrt(cov_lag[1])  # Unconditional SD
σ_ζ = σ_ε * sqrt(1 - ρ^2)  # Innovation SD

println("Unconditional SD: σ_ε = ", round(σ_ε, digits=3))
println("Innovation SD: σ_ζ = ", round(σ_ζ, digits=3))

Model Setup

# utility
utility(c, σ) = c^(1 - σ) / (1 - σ)

# tauchen method
function tauchen(N, ρ, σ)
    # Unconditional standard deviation of the process
    σ_y = σ / sqrt(1 - ρ^2)

    # Create the grid
    y_max = 3. * σ_y
    y_min = - 3. * σ_y
    grid = range(y_min, y_max, length=N)

    # Step size
    step = (y_max - y_min) / (N - 1)

    # Initialize transition matrix
    Π = zeros(N, N)

    # Standard normal distribution
    d = Normal(0, 1)

    # Fill in the transition matrix
    for i in 1:N
        for j in 1:N
            if j == 1
                # Probability of transitioning to the lowest state
                Π[j, i] = cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] + step/2) / σ)
            elseif j == N
                # Probability of transitioning to the highest state
                Π[j, i] = 1 - cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] - step/2) / σ)
            else
                # Probability of transitioning to intermediate states
                Π[j, i] = cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] + step/2) / σ) -
                         cdf(d, (grid[j] - ρ * grid[i] - step/2) / σ)
            end
        end
    end
    return collect(grid), Π
end

# solve the model
function solve_model(p)
    (;T, Π, asset_grid) = p
    K_a = length(asset_grid)
    K_y = size(Π, 1)
    V = zeros(K_y, K_a, T+1)
    A = zeros(K_y, K_a, T)
    for t in reverse(1:T)
        iterate_value_function!(p, V, A, t)
    end
    return (;V, A)
end

function iterate_value_function!(p, V, A, t)
    for ai in axes(V, 2), yi in axes(V, 1)
        v, a_next = solve_value(ai, yi, V, p, t)
        V[yi, ai, t] = v
        A[yi, ai, t] = a_next
    end
end

function solve_value(ai, yi, V, p, t)
    (;σ, β, Π, r, asset_grid, income_grid, net_income) = p
    a = asset_grid[ai]
    y = exp(income_grid[yi, t])
    y_net = net_income(y)
    vmax = -Inf
    amax = 0
    for ai_next in eachindex(asset_grid)
        a_next = asset_grid[ai_next]
        c = y_net + a - a_next/(1+r)
        if c > 0
            @views v = utility(c, σ) + β * dot(Π[:, yi], V[:, ai_next, t+1])
            if v > vmax
                vmax = v
                amax = a_next
            end
        end
    end
    return vmax, amax
end

function solve_steady_state(Π)
    K = size(Π, 2)
    vals, e = eigen(Π)

text:
Interpretation
With the calibrated income process from the PSID data:

Persistence: The estimated ρ ≈ 0.98 indicates that income shocks are highly persistent, close to a random walk.

In Heathcote et al. (2023), the Household Pooling index \(HP_{t}\) is defined as \[ HP_{t} = \frac{var(y_{it}) - var(\bar{y}_{it})}{var(y_{it})}\] where \(\bar{y}_{it}\) is per-person income for household \(i\) at time \(t\). Calculate this index when \(y\) is defined solely as labor market earnings (i.e. wage earnings) and when \(y\) is defined as labor market + business income. Plot both lines to compare them and comment on any differences.

The code block below calculates equivalized income and calculates the pooling measure for each measure of income:

pooling = @chain data begin
    @subset .!ismissing.(:CPSID) #<- drop all obs where this variable is missing (all of 1970)
    @select :CPSID :CPSIDP :YEAR :EARN :INCWAGE
    stack(Not([:CPSID,:CPSIDP,:YEAR]))
    groupby([:YEAR,:CPSID,:variable])
    @transform :value_equiv = mean(:value)
    @groupby([:YEAR,:variable])
    @combine :pooling = (var(:value) - var(:value_equiv)) / var(:value)
    #unstack([:YEAR,:CPSID],:variable,:value)
end

@df pooling plot(:YEAR,:pooling,group=:variable)




  
    
  



  
    
  



  
    
  






























This way of making the calculation is a particular weighting scheme that weights each pooled value \(\bar{y}_{it}\) according to the number of individuals in the household. An alternative would be the unweighted version, which looks like this:

var_pooled = @chain data begin
    @subset .!ismissing.(:CPSID) #<- drop all obs where this variable is missing (all of 1970)
    @select :CPSID :CPSIDP :YEAR :EARN :INCWAGE
    stack(Not([:CPSID,:CPSIDP,:YEAR]))
    groupby([:YEAR,:CPSID,:variable])
    @combine :value_equiv = mean(:value)
    @groupby([:YEAR,:variable])
    @combine :var_pooled = var(:value_equiv)
end

pooling_alt = @chain data begin
    @subset .!ismissing.(:CPSID) #<- drop all obs where this variable is missing (all of 1970)
    @select :CPSID :CPSIDP :YEAR :EARN :INCWAGE
    stack(Not([:CPSID,:CPSIDP,:YEAR]))
    groupby([:YEAR,:variable])
    @combine :var = var(:value)
    innerjoin(_,var_pooled,on=[:YEAR,:variable])
    @transform :pooling = (:var .- :var_pooled) ./ :var
end

@df pooling_alt plot(:YEAR,:pooling,group=:variable)

Consider the life-cycle model we have used in Assignment 2 and Recitation 4. Assume that the income process is as follows:
\[ y_{it} = \mu_{t} + \alpha_{i} + \zeta_{it} + \epsilon_{it} \]
where
\[ \zeta_{it} = \rho \zeta_{it-1} + \eta_{it} \]
and \(\alpha_{i}\), \(\epsilon_{it}\), and \(\eta_{it}\) are iid, with \(\epsilon_{it}\sim N(0,\sigma_{\epsilon}^2)\), \(\eta_{it}\sim N(0,\sigma^2_{\eta})\). Let \(\sigma^2_{\alpha} = \mathbb{V}[\alpha_{i}]\) and let \(\mathbb{E}[\alpha_{i}]=0\) such that \(\mathbb{E}[y_{it}] = \mu_{t}\).
You are going to estimate the parameters of this income process using the psid data from Recitation 4 and repeat the welfare analysis from that session.

Repeating the analysis from class, show that the following relationships hold under the assumptions above: \[ \begin{align}
\mathbb{V}[y_{it}] = \sigma^2_{\alpha} + \mathbb{V}[\zeta_{it}] + \sigma^2_{\epsilon} \\
\mathbb{C}(y_{it},y_{it+s}) = \sigma^2_{\alpha} + \rho^{s}\mathbb{V}[\zeta_{it}]
\end{align}
\] (this question requires only math)
Use these relationships above to express the parameters \((\rho,\sigma^2_{\epsilon},\sigma^2_{\eta},\sigma^2_{\alpha})\) in terms of variances and lagged covariances. A hint: start by showing something like: \[
\rho = \frac{\mathbb{C}(y_{it},y_{it+3}) - \mathbb{C}(y_{it},y_{it+2})}{\mathbb{C}(y_{it},y_{it+2}) - \mathbb{C}(y_{it},y_{it+1})}.
\] Then you can assume you know \(\rho\), use this to get \(\mathbb{V}[\zeta_{it}]\), then \(\sigma^2_{\alpha}\), then finally \(\sigma^2_{\epsilon}\). (this question requires only math)
Following the steps in Recitation 4, use your answers to question 2 to construct estimates of the parameters of the income process, \((\mu,\rho,\sigma^2_{\epsilon},\sigma^2_{\eta},\sigma^2_{\alpha})\). Note: you will need to adjust the strategy above to account for the fact that the PSID only has data every two years. (this question requires code)
How does the estimate of \(\rho\) compare to the estimate from Recitation 4? Please provide some intuition for why.
(extra credit, 3%) Repeat the analysis of Recitation 4 (where we introduced a progressive tax) with this new income process and comment on differences you find in overall welfare impacts and differences in the insurance vs redistribution decomposition. You should use the function below, which uses our previous function tauchen.jl to construct a transition matrix \(\Pi\) to approximate the income process above, assuming that \(\alpha_{i}\) can take one of three evenly spaced grid points with equal probability, and assuming that \(\epsilon_{it}\) is measurement error (i.e. does not reflect real changes in income).


using LinearAlgebra

function approx_income_process(N, ρ, σ, σ_α)
    # use tauchen method to approximate the AR(1) component
    egrid, Π = tauchen(N, ρ, σ)
    agrid = [-sqrt(3/2)*σ_α, 0., sqrt(3/2)*σ_α]
    # construct a larger grid of α .+ egrid for each α
    grid = [α + e for α in agrid for e in egrid]
    # create a larger transition matrix where the
    # probability of moving from α to any other α' is zero
    Π = kron(I(3),Π)
    return grid, Π
end

text:
Consider the income process:
\[y_{it} = \alpha_i + \xi_{it} + \varepsilon_{it}\]
where \(\xi_{it} = \rho \xi_{it-1} + \eta_{it}\) and \(\eta_{it}, \varepsilon_{it}\) are iid with \(\mathbb{V}[\alpha_i] = \sigma_\alpha^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\eta_{it}] = \sigma_\eta^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\varepsilon_{it}] = \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\).
Use population moments to argue that the parameters \(\sigma_\alpha^2, \rho, \sigma_\eta^2, \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\) can be identified with panel data. Note that \(\sigma^2_{\varepsilon,t}\) is specific to the age \(t\).






Solution





Variance of income:
\[\mathbb{V}[y_{it}] = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
\[\mathbb{V}[y_{it+1}] = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \sigma_\eta^2 + \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
Covariances:
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+3}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^3 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
Identification:
\[\rho = \frac{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+3}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2})}{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1})} = \frac{(\rho^3 - \rho^2) \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}{(\rho^2 - \rho) \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}\]
\[\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \frac{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1})}{\rho^2 - \rho}\]
\[\sigma_\alpha^2 = \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) - \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2 = \mathbb{V}[y_{it}] - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) \quad \text{for each } t\]
\[\sigma_\eta^2 = \mathbb{V}[y_{it+1}] - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) - \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
Done.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Basic Setup
There are 5 basic ingredients in the model:


In each period \(t\), one generation of adults raises the next generation for \(t+1\) (an “OLG” framework)
Care only about consumption, with an altruistic weight \(\beta\) on future generations
Can transfer wealth through:

Financial assets \(A_{t}\), with rate of return \(r\); or
Human capital, \(H_{t}\), with price \(w\) (the wage)

A production function converts investments \(X_{t}\) into human capital \(H_{t+1}\)
An ability endowment, \(z_{t}\), evolves exogenously.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
section: A recursive formulation of the model
text:
A recursive formulation of the model
Let \(\Omega_{t} = A_{t} + wH_{t}\) be total wealth in period \(t\):
\[ V(\Omega_{t},z_{t}) = \max_{X_{t},Z_{t}}\left\{ u(C_{t}) + \beta \mathbb{E}[V(\Omega_{t+1},z_{t+1})] \right\} \]
subject to:
\[
\begin{eqnarray}
C_{t} + \psi X_{t} + \frac{A_{t+1}}{1+r} \leq \Omega_{t} \\
\Omega_{t+1} = A_{t+1} + wH_{t+1} \\
z_{t+1} = \rho z_{t} + \eta_{t+1} \\
H_{t+1} = z_{t}X_{t}^{\delta}
\end{eqnarray}
\]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Reading




Becker, Gary S., and Nigel Tomes. 1979. “An Equilibrium Theory of the Distribution of Income and Intergenerational Mobility.” The Journal of Political Economy, no. 6: 1153–89. https://doi.org/10.1086/260831.


———. 1986. “Human Capital and the Rise and Fall of Families.” Journal of Labor Economics, no. 3: S1–39. https://doi.org/10.1086/298118.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
A Simple Version
Here is a simple version that captures important forces:


Ability is mean-reverting: \[ z_{t+1} = \rho z_{t} + \eta_{t+1},\ \rho \in(0,1) \]
Human capital production: \[ H_{t+1} = \exp(\mu + z_{t})X_{t}^{\delta} \] where \(X_{t}\) has price \(\psi\)
Budget constraint: \[ C_{t} + \frac{A_{t+1}}{1+r} + \psi X_{t} \leq A_{t} + wH_{t} \]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
A recursive formulation
Let \(\Omega_{t} = A_{t} + wH_{t}\) be total wealth in period \(t\):
\[ V(\Omega_{t},z_{t}) = \max_{C_{t},X_{t},A_{t+1}}\left\{ u(C_{t}) + \beta \mathbb{E}[V(\Omega_{t+1},z_{t+1})] \right\} \]
subject to:
\[
\begin{eqnarray}
C_{t} + \psi X_{t} + \frac{A_{t+1}}{1+r} \leq \Omega_{t} \\
\Omega_{t+1} = A_{t+1} + wH_{t+1} \\
z_{t+1} = \rho z_{t} + \eta_{t+1} \\
H_{t+1} = \exp(\mu+z_{t})X_{t}^{\delta}
\end{eqnarray}
\]
. . .
Note: no constraints on borrowing (for now)

Model Solution


This is quite a simple model, but we can learn some interesting and useful things from it
We’ll show that investment does not depend on wealth or income

Result 3: The Long-Run Effects of Good Fortune
What is the long-run effect of an increase in \(z\)?


To do this, let’s assume that \(\beta(1+r) = 1\) for simplicity
We’ll take a derivative around the deterministic steady state

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Takeaways so far


Investment does not depend on income (when borrowing is unconstrained)
Human capital differences fade away, but consumption effects last forever
Rich households use wealth bequests to maintain dynasties as human capital fades away
IGE determined by ability persistence (\(\rho\)) and human capital production (\(\delta\))
But is this realistic? What about credit constraints?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Connecting to IGE Estimation
Recall from last lecture we estimated:
\[y_{\text{child}} = \alpha + \beta \cdot y_{\text{parent}} + \varepsilon\]


In this model: \(\beta = \rho\) (ability persistence)
Independent of technology parameter \(\delta\)
Independent of prices \(w\), \(\psi\), \(r\)
Policy invariant: transfers don’t change IGE


. . .
Think: Is this consistent with geographic variation in mobility we saw?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Why Start with Two Periods?


Simplify exposition of some key points
Two-period version captures key forces
Lessons generalize

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Two-Period Setup
Parent’s problem in period 1:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2, X} u(C_1) + \beta u(C_2)\]
subject to:
\[
\begin{eqnarray}
C_1 + \psi X + \frac{A'}{1+r} &\leq& \Omega \\
C_2 &=& A' + w z X^{\delta}
\end{eqnarray}
\]


\(\Omega = wH + A\): total lifetime wealth
\(A'\): bequests (can be negative = borrowing)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Combining Budget Constraints
Combining the two constraints:
\[C_1 + \frac{1}{1+r} C_2 \leq \Omega + \frac{w z X^{\delta}}{1+r} - \psi X\]


Left side: present value of consumption
Right side: wealth plus net human capital investment
Net investment: returns \(\frac{w z X^{\delta}}{1+r}\) but costs \(\psi X\)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
First-Order Conditions
Euler equation:
\[u'(C_1) = \beta(1+r) u'(C_2)\]
. . .
FOC with respect to \(X\):
\[\psi = \frac{\delta w z X^{\delta-1}}{1+r}\]
. . .
Same result as before on optimal \(X\).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
section: Investment Does Not Depend on Income
text:
Investment Does Not Depend on Income
From the FOCs, we can derive:
\[X^* = \left( \frac{\delta w z}{\psi(1+r)} \right)^{\frac{1}{1-\delta}}\]


Notice: \(X^*\) depends on \(z\), \(w\), \(\psi\), \(r\), \(\delta\)
But not on \(\Omega\) (lifetime wealth)!
This is the key “income independence” result
Holds because parents can borrow/lend at rate \(r\)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
With Log Utility
If \(u(C) = \log(C)\), we can solve explicitly:
From Euler equation: \[\frac{C_2}{C_1} = \beta(1+r)\]
Therefore: \[(1+\beta)C_1 = \Omega + \frac{w z X^{*\delta}}{1+r} - \psi X^{*}\]
Where \[X^* = \left( \frac{\delta w z}{\psi(1+r)} \right)^{\frac{1}{1-\delta}}\]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Interpretation
What does this mean economically?


Parents optimize to equate marginal returns across uses
Rich and poor parents with same \(z\) invest the same in children
Differences in income absorbed by \(C_1\), \(C_2\), and \(A\)
Crucial assumption: can borrow against future returns to H.C. investment


. . .
Question: Is this realistic? What if parents can’t borrow?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Is the Market Outcome Efficient?
Consider a social planner who maximizes weighted welfare:
\[\max_{\{C_{i1}, C_{i2}, X_i\}_{i\in[0,1]}} \int \left(\mu_{i1} u(C_{i1}) + \mu_{i2} u(C_{i2})\right)di\]
subject to resource constraint:
\[\int C_{i1} di + \frac{1}{1+r} \int C_{i2} di \leq \int \Omega_i di + \frac{w}{1+r} \int z_i X_i^{\delta} di - \psi \int X_i di\]
. . .
Key question: Does the planner’s solution coincide with the market?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Planner’s First-Order Conditions
The planner’s FOCs are:
\[\frac{u'(C_{i1})}{u'(C_{i2})} = \frac{\mu_{i2}}{\mu_{i1}}, \quad \frac{\delta w z_i X_i^{\delta-1}}{1+r} = \psi\]
Compare to market FOCs:
\[\frac{u'(C_{i1})}{u'(C_{i2})} = \beta(1+r), \quad \frac{\delta w z_{i} X_{i}^{\delta-1}}{1+r} = \psi\]


Investment is identical: \(X_i^* = X_i^{planner}\)
Only difference: consumption allocation via weights \(\mu_{i1}, \mu_{i2}\)
Market outcome is efficient for some choice of weights

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Efficiency Interpretation
What does this mean?


The market outcome is Pareto efficient
“can’t make anyone better off without making someone worse off”
Relative to Laissez-Faire economy, Planner can redistribute but that’s it


. . .
But: This relies critically on perfect credit markets!

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
What If Parents Can’t Borrow?
Now impose borrowing constraint:
\[A \geq 0\]
This means:
\[C_2 = A + w z X^{\delta} \geq w z X^{\delta}\]


Bequests must be non-negative
Parents cannot borrow against child’s future earnings
This creates a fundamental change in the model

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Binding Constraint Case
When \(A = 0\) binds, the problem becomes:
\[\max_{C_1, X} u(C_1) + \beta u(w z X^{\delta})\] \[\text{s.t. } C_1 + \psi X \leq \Omega\]
FOC with respect to \(X\):
\[u'(C_1) = \beta u'(C_2) \cdot \delta w z X^{\delta-1}\]
With log utility: \[\frac{C_1}{X} = \frac{1}{\psi} - \frac{\beta \delta w z}{\psi} \frac{1}{1 + \beta \delta w z}\]

Key difference: Now \(X\) depends on \(\Omega\)!

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
When do constraints bind?


Solve for \(X^*\) when \(A=0\): \[ \max_{X} u(\Omega - \psi X) + \beta u(wzX^{\delta}) \]
With log utility: \[ X^* = \frac{1}{\psi}\frac{\beta\delta}{1+\beta\delta} \Omega \]
Note that \(X^{*}\) now depends on \(\Omega\)

Policy Options
Given that \(z\) is unobservable, what can policy do?


Income-targeted transfers: Help poor families (some high-\(z\) children)
Progressive taxation: Redistribute from unconstrained to constrained
Public investment: Direct provision of education/childcare
Trade-off: Gains from relaxing constraints vs. distortions from taxation

\[\max_{C_1, C_2, X} u(C_1) + \beta u(C_2)\]
subject to:

Equilibriums is inefficient.

\[\frac{1}{\psi}\frac{\beta \delta }{1 + \beta \delta} \Omega \leq \left( \frac{\delta w z}{\psi(1+r)} \right)^{\frac{1}{1-\delta}}\]


More likely to bind when \(\Omega\) is low (poor families)
More likely to bind when \(z\) is high (high returns to investment)
Creates a region where investment increases with income
