title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Previous lecture: geographic variation in mobility
Today: theory of intergenerational transmission
The Becker-Tomes model (Becker and Tomes 1979, 1986)
Key questions:

Why do earnings regress to the mean?
How do parents affect children’s outcomes?
What determines the speed of mobility?

Building a unified framework for inequality and mobility

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Three Channels of Transmission
Parents affect children through:


Endowments (genes and culture): \(E_t\)

IQ, personality, work ethic, cultural capital

Human capital investments: \(x_t\)

Education, training, health, early childhood

Financial transfers: bequests and gifts

Assets, property, cash transfers



. . .
Each channel has different properties for transmission across generations.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Endowment Transmission
Endowments follow a Markov process:
\[E_t = \alpha + h E_{t-1} + v_t\]


\(h\) = inheritability parameter (how much is passed on)
\(0 < h < 1\): endowments regress to the mean
\(\alpha\) = social endowment (common to all)
\(v_t\) = random luck in endowment transmission


. . .
Think: What does \(h < 1\) imply for children of high-ability parents?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Why Does h < 1?


Genetics: Mendel’s laws → regression to the mean

Child gets random draw from parents’ genes
Extreme traits don’t fully transmit

Culture: imperfect transmission of values/habits

Peer effects, media, broader environment matter

Empirical evidence: \(h \approx 0.3\) to \(0.6\) for earnings-relevant traits


. . .
This automatic regression is key to understanding mobility.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Generation
Adult earnings depend on human capital and luck:
\[Y_t = H_t + \varepsilon_t\]
where human capital is produced by:
\[H_t = \psi(x_{t-1}, s_{t-1}, E_t)\]


\(x_{t-1}\) = parental investments
\(s_{t-1}\) = public investments (schools, etc.)
\(E_t\) = endowments
\(\psi\) is increasing in all three inputs

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Complementarity
Key assumption: endowments and investments are complements
\[\frac{\partial^2 H_t}{\partial x_{t-1} \partial E_t} > 0\]


Higher ability → higher return to education
Better endowed children get more from investments
Reinforces initial advantages
Creates skewness in earnings distribution


. . .
Question: Does this match your intuition about returns to education?

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Wealth-Maximizing Case
Suppose parents can borrow freely against children’s future earnings.
Then they solve: \[\max_{x_{t-1}} \quad H_t(x_{t-1}, E_t) - (1+r) x_{t-1}\]
First-order condition: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} = 1 + r\]
. . .
Implication: Marginal return on human capital = interest rate for ALL families.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Investment with Perfect Markets





  
    
  



  
    
  



  
    
  






































Higher endowment → higher optimal investment (even at same r).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings with Perfect Markets
Substitute optimal \(x^*\) into earnings:
\[Y_t = H_t(x^*(E_t), E_t) + \varepsilon_t = \phi(E_t, r) + \varepsilon_t\]
Replace \(E_t\) using the Markov process:
\[Y_t = c_t + h \cdot Y_{t-1} + \text{error terms}\]


Key result: earnings regress at rate \(1-h\)
Speed of regression = inheritability of endowments
No direct effect of parents’ income (perfect credit markets!)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Consumption and Bequests
With perfect markets, parents choose bequests to satisfy:
\[u'(Z_t) = \delta (1+r) u'(Z_{t+1})\]


If \(\delta(1+r) = 1\): consumption growth = 0
Consumption does not regress to mean!
Parents use bequests to offset earnings regression
Rich parents leave large bequests to maintain consumption


. . .
Surprising: Perfect mobility in earnings, but dynasties persist in consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Realistic Case
Most families cannot borrow against children’s future earnings.


Human capital is poor collateral
Moral hazard: children can shirk
Legal restrictions: can’t obligate children for parents’ debt


. . .
Implication: Parents must self-finance investments in children.
Now parents’ income matters for investments!

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Constrained Optimization
Parents without assets must trade off:

Own consumption \(Z_t\)
Investment in children \(x_{t-1}\)

This means: \[\frac{\partial H_t}{\partial x_{t-1}} > 1 + r\]
. . .
Marginal return on human capital exceeds interest rate for poor families.
Why? Reducing \(x\) raises marginal utility of parents’ consumption.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Investment with Capital Constraints





Poorer families invest less due to higher marginal cost of funds.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Earnings Regression with Constraints
Now earnings depend on both endowments AND parents’ income:
\[Y_t = \phi(E_t, Y_{t-1}, s_{t-1})\]


\(\frac{\partial Y_t}{\partial Y_{t-1}} = \beta^* > 0\) (income effect)
Richer parents invest more in children
Creates additional persistence beyond \(h\)
Two-generation regression equation:


\[Y_t \approx c_t + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \text{errors}\]

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Three-Generation Test
The model predicts:

Positive coefficient on parents’ earnings: \(\beta^* + h\)
Negative coefficient on grandparents’ earnings: \(-\beta^* h\)



Grandparents matter through their effect on parents
But holding parents’ earnings fixed, rich grandparents ↔︎ rich parents ↔︎ lower investments needed
This negative coefficient is testable!
Evidence (limited): Wahl (1985) finds negative coefficient

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Efficiency Loss from Constraints
Capital constraints cause inefficiency:


Marginal return is higher in poor families
But they invest less
Redistributing investment from rich → poor would raise total output
Equity and efficiency both favor helping poor families
Justifies subsidies to education for disadvantaged children


. . .
Policy implication: Progressive education funding can be efficiency-enhancing.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Public Investments
How do public expenditures \(s_t\) affect the system?


If perfect substitutes for \(x_t\): partial crowd-out

Rich families reduce \(x_t\) dollar-for-dollar
Poor families reduce less (still constrained)

If complements (e.g., subsidize tuition → raises return to parental time):

Can increase total investment
Substitution effect works against redistribution effect



. . .
Evidence: Many programs show weak effects due to family offsetting behavior.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Fertility
Allow number of children \(n_t\) to vary:
\[U_t = u(Z_t) + \alpha(n_t) n_t U_{t+1}\]
with \(\alpha'(n_t) < 0\) (diminishing marginal utility of children).


Richer families have more children
This dilutes bequests per child
Induces regression in wealth per child
Helps explain why dynasties don’t persist forever

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Marriage
Assortative mating: tendency to marry someone similar.


Positive correlation in spouses’ endowments
But imperfect: \(\text{corr}(E_{\text{mother}}, E_{\text{father}}) < 1\)
Child’s endowment = average of parents
Marriage causes additional regression to mean
Empirically: education correlation ≈ 0.6, earnings ≈ 0.3


. . .
Combined effect: fertility + marriage ensure consumption/wealth regress over time.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Discrimination
Discrimination affects both the intercept and returns:
\[Y_t = \phi(E_t, Y_{t-1}) - D_t\]


\(D_t\) = earnings loss from discrimination
Lower earnings → tighter capital constraints
Prediction: faster upward mobility among discriminated groups

Their marginal returns are higher
When discrimination reduces, they catch up faster

Evidence: Black families show faster regression (maybe)

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Predicted Regression Coefficients
The model predicts:

Coefficient
Typical value




Father → son earnings
\(\beta^* + h\)
0.2 - 0.4


Father → son (rich families)
\(h\)
0.3 - 0.5

Negative, small


Father → son wealth
Higher (0.5 - 0.7)






Earnings regress faster than wealth
Most advantages disappear in 3 generations
But family background still matters significantly

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The “Shirtsleeves to Shirtsleeves” Result
“From shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations.”


If \(b = 0.4\): parent earning 2× mean → child earns 1.4× → grandchild earns 1.16×
After 3 generations: essentially at the mean
Rapid intergenerational mobility in earnings
But this is conditional on no discrimination, equal opportunity


. . .
Key insight: Even modest regression rates wipe out advantages quickly.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Consumption vs. Earnings Mobility
The model distinguishes:

Earnings: regress due to endowments (\(h < 1\)) and capital constraints
Consumption: buffered by bequests in rich families



Perfect markets → consumption doesn’t regress (dynasties)
Imperfect markets → consumption regresses faster in poor families
Fertility/marriage → consumption regresses even in rich families
Empirically: wealth regresses slower than earnings

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Policy Implications
From the Becker-Tomes framework:


Education subsidies: Address capital constraints, raise efficiency
Progressive taxation: May increase OR decrease long-run inequality

Reduces bequests → more regression
But also reduces investment incentives

Early childhood programs: High returns if:

Target capital-constrained families
Truly complement (not substitute) family investments

Meritocracy requires more than talent

Need to overcome capital constraints
Otherwise ability doesn’t determine outcomes

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Limitations and Extensions
What the basic model misses:


Multiple skills: cognitive, non-cognitive, health
Life-cycle dynamics: when do investments matter most?
Neighborhoods and peers: external effects on children
Uncertainty: parents don’t know child’s future fully
Credit constraints: can vary over time/development


. . .
Modern research extends the model in these directions.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
The Goldberger Critique
Goldberger (1989) raised a fundamental question:


Are Becker-Tomes predictions distinct from simple Galton model?
Galton: \(Y_t = \alpha + h Y_{t-1} + \varepsilon_t\) (just genetics)
Becker-Tomes adds: investments, capital markets, bequests
Question: Do these additions generate unique testable predictions?
Or do we just get the same regression-to-mean result?


. . .
This motivated systematic testing of unique Becker-Tomes implications.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Mulligan’s Empirical Tests
Mulligan (1999) tests 9 unique implications of Becker-Tomes vs. Galton:


Uses multiple datasets: PSID, NLS, SCF
Examines earnings, consumption, and wealth
Distinguishes families by transfer behavior
Result: Several key predictions fail empirically


. . .
Let’s examine the most important failures.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 1: Consumption Mobility
Becker-Tomes prediction: With perfect credit markets, consumption should not regress to mean among transfer-making families.

Rich parents use bequests to offset earnings regression
Dynasty persists in consumption even as earnings regress



Evidence (Mulligan (1999), Table 3): Consumption does regress!
Among families making transfers: \(\beta_{\text{consumption}} \approx 0.3\)
Similar to earnings regression
Suggests credit markets are NOT perfect even for rich families

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 2: Earnings Inequality
Becker-Tomes prediction: Families making transfers (unconstrained) should have more equal children’s earnings than constrained families.

Why? Unconstrained families equate marginal returns
Only endowment variation matters, not income variation
Constrained families: both endowments AND income matter



Evidence (Mulligan (1999), Table 6): Opposite pattern!
Children of transfer-making families have more earnings inequality
Suggests complementarity between parental resources and outcomes
Basic two-period model misses something important

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Failed Prediction 3: The Grandparent Effect
Becker-Tomes prediction: Controlling for parents’ income, grandparents’ income should have negative effect.
\[Y_t \approx c_t + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \varepsilon_t\]


Intuition: Rich grandparents → rich parents → less investment needed
Evidence (Mulligan (1999)): Coefficient on \(Y_{t-2}\) is positive or zero
Not the predicted negative relationship
Suggests longer-run dynamics than two-generation model

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
What’s Missing?
The failures point to important omissions:


Multi-period structure: Investments span childhood, not one shot
Multiple skills: Cognitive and non-cognitive abilities matter
Dynamic complementarity: Early investments affect returns to later ones
Self-productivity: Skills today enhance skill formation tomorrow
Life-cycle timing: When investments occur matters


. . .
Solution: Extend to multi-period framework with richer technology.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Cunha-Heckman Technology
Cunha and Heckman (2007) develop a multi-stage model of skill formation:
\[\theta_{t+1} = f_t(h, \theta_t, I_t)\]


\(\theta_t\) = vector of skills at age \(t\) (cognitive, non-cognitive)
\(I_t\) = vector of investments at age \(t\) (parental, public)
\(h\) = child’s genetic endowment
\(f_t\) = age-specific production function


. . .
Key: Production function changes over development stages.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Two Key Properties

1. Self-Productivity
\[\frac{\partial \theta_{t+1}}{\partial \theta_t} > 0\]
Skills acquired in one period boost skill formation in the next period.


Learning-to-learn
Higher ability children accumulate skills faster
Creates compounding advantages
Explains why early gaps widen over time

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Two Key Properties (continued)

2. Dynamic Complementarity
\[\frac{\partial^2 \theta_{t+1}}{\partial I_t \partial \theta_t} > 0\]
Higher skill stocks raise the productivity of subsequent investments.


Investment is more productive for already-skilled children
Early investments raise returns to later investments
Creates path dependence
Different from static complementarity in basic model

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
A Simple Two-Period Example
Suppose skills evolve over two childhood periods:
\[\theta_1 = f_0(h, I_0)\] \[\theta_2 = f_1(h, \theta_1, I_1)\]
Adult earnings: \(Y = H(\theta_2) + \varepsilon\)


Early investment \(I_0\) affects \(\theta_1\) directly
But also affects productivity of \(I_1\) (dynamic complementarity)
And \(\theta_1\) affects \(\theta_2\) directly (self-productivity)
Total effect of \(I_0\) includes three channels

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
CES Specification
Cunha and Heckman (2007) use a CES production function:
\[\theta_{t+1} = \left[\gamma_1 \theta_t^\phi + \gamma_2 I_t^\phi\right]^{1/\phi}\]


\(\phi\) determines elasticity of substitution: \(\sigma = 1/(1-\phi)\)
\(\phi < 1\): Skills and investment are complements
\(\gamma_1, \gamma_2\): relative importance of self-productivity vs. investment
Can estimate separately for different ages and skill types


. . .
Empirical finding: \(\phi < 0\) for early childhood (strong complementarity).

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Critical and Sensitive Periods
The multi-period framework allows for:


Critical periods: Times when \(\partial f_t / \partial I_t\) is especially high

Investment has large direct effect
Example: Language acquisition 0-3 years

Sensitive periods: Times when complementarity is strongest

Investment affects returns to all future investments
Example: Executive function development 3-5 years

Empirical evidence: Early childhood is both critical and sensitive

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Rationalizing the Evidence
The multi-period model addresses Mulligan’s critiques:


Consumption mobility: Multiple constraints over child’s development

Can’t borrow against future at each stage
Even rich families face some constraints

Earnings inequality: Dynamic complementarity reinforces advantages

Rich parents invest more at ALL stages
Complementarities amplify initial differences

Grandparent effects: Longer transmission chain

\(Y_{t-2}\) affects multiple periods of \(Y_{t-1}\)’s development
Positive persistence through multiple channels

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Policy Implications from Multi-Period Model
The timing of intervention matters:


Early investments have high returns

Affect all subsequent stages through complementarity
Self-productivity multiplies initial effects
Equity and efficiency align for early programs

Late remediation is costly

Must overcome accumulated deficits
Low complementarity with missing early skills
Equity-efficiency tradeoff emerges

Targeting matters

Complementarity → target disadvantaged children early
Universal programs may have low returns if constraints don’t bind

Cognitive and non-cognitive skills from test scores
Investments from time use and expenditures
Key findings:

Self-productivity dominates investment by adolescence
Optimal investment front-loaded to early ages
Explains fadeout of programs that don’t continue investing



. . .
Conclusion: Multi-stage technology rationalizes patterns that puzzle basic Becker-Tomes.

title: The Becker-Tomes Model
text:
Summary
The Becker-Tomes model provides a unified framework:


Endowment regression (\(h < 1\)) drives mobility
Capital constraints slow mobility for poor families
Bequests buffer consumption regression for rich families
Fertility and marriage ensure long-run regression
Parents affect children through multiple channels
Policy can address market failures efficiently

title: The Becker-Tomes Model

Key Equations
For reference:

Endowment transmission: \(E_t = \alpha + h E_{t-1} + v_t\)
Human capital production: \(H_t = \psi(x_{t-1}, E_t, s_{t-1})\)
Earnings (no constraints): \(Y_t \approx \alpha + h \cdot Y_{t-1} + \varepsilon_t\)
Earnings (with constraints): \(Y_t \approx \alpha + (\beta^* + h) Y_{t-1} - \beta^* h \cdot Y_{t-2} + \varepsilon_t\)

Understanding these relationships is key to analyzing mobility policy.

title: Practice Exercises
text:
Consider the income process:
\[y_{it} = \alpha_i + \xi_{it} + \varepsilon_{it}\]
where \(\xi_{it} = \rho \xi_{it-1} + \eta_{it}\) and \(\eta_{it}, \varepsilon_{it}\) are iid with \(\mathbb{V}[\alpha_i] = \sigma_\alpha^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\eta_{it}] = \sigma_\eta^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\varepsilon_{it}] = \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\).
Use population moments to argue that the parameters \(\sigma_\alpha^2, \rho, \sigma_\eta^2, \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\) can be identified with panel data. Note that \(\sigma^2_{\varepsilon,t}\) is specific to the age \(t\).






Solution





Variance of income:
\[\mathbb{V}[y_{it}] = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
\[\mathbb{V}[y_{it+1}] = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \sigma_\eta^2 + \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
Covariances:
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+3}) = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^3 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
Identification:
\[\rho = \frac{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+3}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2})}{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1})} = \frac{(\rho^3 - \rho^2) \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}{(\rho^2 - \rho) \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}\]
\[\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \frac{\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) - \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1})}{\rho^2 - \rho}\]
\[\sigma_\alpha^2 = \mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) - \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2 = \mathbb{V}[y_{it}] - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) \quad \text{for each } t\]
\[\sigma_\eta^2 = \mathbb{V}[y_{it+1}] - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) - \sigma_{\varepsilon,t}^2\]
Done.

section: Problem 3: One-Period Model with Lognormal Income
text:
Problem 3: One-Period Model with Lognormal Income
Consider the following one period model:
\[C_i = Y_i = \exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)\]
where \(\varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2)\), \(\alpha_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2)\). Suppose that \(\alpha_i\) is known to each individual and \(\varepsilon_i\) is income risk. Assume log utility s.t. \(V(\alpha_i) = \mathbb{E}[\log(C_i) | \alpha_i]\).

Part (a)
Show that \(V(\alpha_i) = \alpha_i\).






Solution





\[V(\alpha_i) = \mathbb{E}[\log(C_i) | \alpha_i] = \mathbb{E}[\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i | \alpha_i] = \alpha_i\]





Part (b)
Suppose a planner solves:
\[\max_{\{C_i\}_{i\in[0,1]}} \int \log(C_i) di \quad \text{s.t.} \quad \int C_i di = \int \exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)di\]
Show that the solution is
\[C_i^* = C^* = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\]
Hint: if \(Z \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2)\), \(\mathbb{E}[\exp(Z)] = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2)\).






Solution





Since \(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2 + \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2)\), \(\int\exp(\alpha_{i}+\varepsilon_{i})di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\).
Planner’s FOC: \(\frac{1}{C_i} = \lambda \quad \forall \, i\)
where \(\lambda\) is multiplier on resource constraint. Hence \(C_i = C^* \quad \forall \, i\).
Plugging into resource constraint gives
\[C^* = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\]





Part (c)
Show that the certainty equivalent \(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)\) that delivers \(V(\alpha_i)\) is \(\overline{C}(\alpha_i) = \exp(\alpha_i)\).






Solution





\(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)\) solves
\[\log(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)) = V(\alpha_i) = \alpha_i\]
\[\Rightarrow \overline{C}(\alpha_i) = \exp(\alpha_i)\]





Part (d)
Show that \(\overline{C} = \int \overline{C}(\alpha_{i})di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{\alpha})\)






Note





Since \(\alpha_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2)\),
\[\overline{C} = \int \overline{C}(\alpha_i) di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma_\alpha^2)\]





Part (e)
Show that the planner’s objective is \(\mu\) in the baseline and \(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2)\) at the optimum.






Solution





Baseline: \(W = \int \log(C_i) = \int \log(\exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)) di = \mathbb{E}[\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i] = \mu\)
\[W^* = \log(C^*) = \mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2)\]





Part (f)
Decompose \(W^* - W\) into two components:

\(W^* - \log(\overline{C})\)
\(\log(\overline{C}) - W\)

What is (1)? What is (2)? Which term represents the gains from insurance?






Solution






\(W^* - \log(\overline{C}) = \frac{1}{2}\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 \leftarrow\) Insurance
\(\log(\overline{C}) - W = \frac{1}{2}\sigma_\alpha^2 \leftarrow\) Redistribution






Part (g)
Make sense! \(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\) is variance component in \(y_{it}\) coming from risk, \(\sigma_\alpha^2\) is the component coming from ex-ante inequality.






Interpretation





\(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\) measures the variance in income coming from idiosyncratic risk that individuals face. Insurance eliminates this uncertainty.
\(\sigma_\alpha^2\) measures the variance in income coming from permanent differences across individuals (ex-ante inequality). Redistribution addresses this component.

text:
Problem 4: Two-Period Becker-Tomes Model
Consider the 2-period Becker-Tomes model:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2, X, A} U(C_1) + \beta U(C_2)\]
\[\text{s.t.} \quad C_1 + \psi X + A / (1+r) \leq \Omega + T / (1+r)\]
\[C_2 = A + wz X^\delta - T, \quad A \geq 0\]
where \(T\) is a lump-sum tax paid by generation 2 to generation 1.

Part (a)
Show that if a household is not constrained, the value of \(T\) does not affect any allocations of \(C_1, C_2, X\) at the optimum. (Hint: try combining budget constraints).






Solution





If \(A > 0\) at the optimum, can combine to get:
\[C_1 + C_2/(1+r) \leq \Omega + wz X^\delta/(1+r) \quad (*)\]
s.t. household solves:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2} U(C_1) + \beta U(C_2) \quad \text{s.t.} \quad (*)\]
Hence \(T\) does not feature.





Part (b)
Show that for constrained households:
\[U'(C_1) = \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{(1+r)} U'(C_2) \quad \text{and} \quad (1+r) \leq \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\]






Solution





When \(A = 0\), solve:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2} U(\Omega + T/(1+r) - \psi X) + \beta U(wz X^\delta - T)\]
get
\[U'(\Omega + T/(1+r) - \psi X) = \beta \delta wz X^{\delta-1} U'(wz X^\delta - T)\]
\[\Leftrightarrow U'(C_1) \psi = \beta \delta wz^{\delta-1} U'(wz X^\delta - T)\]
Note that the marginal return (in assets) is
\[-\frac{1}{1+r} U'(C_1) + \beta U'(C_2) \leq 0 \quad \Leftrightarrow (1+r) \leq \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\]
(if \(> 0\), then household should optimally increase \(A\) above 0).





Part (c)
Consider a marginal increase in \(T\). What happens to the welfare of constrained vs unconstrained households?






Solution





If \(T \nearrow\) marginally, change in welfare is
\[u'(C_1) \frac{1}{(1+r)} - \beta u'(C_2) > 0\]
for constrained households, where inequality follows from (b).
Since allocations of constrained households are unaffected by \(T\) \(\Rightarrow\) no welfare effect.
Note: not clear if welfare of children \(\nearrow\) in this intervention.

section: Problem 5: Two-Period Model with Progressive Taxation
text:
Problem 5: Two-Period Model with Progressive Taxation
For the same 2-period model, suppose budget constraints are now:
\[C_1 + A/(1+r) + \psi X \leq \lambda_{1} \Omega^{1-\tau}\]
\[C_2 = A + \lambda_2 (wz X^\delta)^{1-\tau}, \quad A \geq 0\]
where \(\lambda_1\) and \(\lambda_2\) are chosen to balance budget in each period.

Part (a)
Write the FOC for unconstrained households.






Solution





For unconstrained:
\[(1+r) = \frac{\lambda_2 (1-\tau) \delta(w z) X^{\delta(1-\tau)-1}}{\psi}\]





Part (b)
Recall that the planner would set, if possible, \((1+r) = \frac{wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\) in each household \(i\). Can the equilibrium with taxation be efficient?






Solution





Comparing to the condition \((1+r) = \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\),
taxation distorts the optimal allocation of financials \(\Rightarrow\) human capital \(\Rightarrow\) not efficient.





Part (c)
Explain, in words, the efficiency cost of progressive taxation in this model. (Hint: compare the household’s FOC to the planner’s).






Solution





Redistribution reduces the incentives for parents to invest. \(\Rightarrow\) An equity-efficiency tradeoff.





Part (d)
Assuming log utility, solve for \(X\) when households are constrained. Comment on solution relative to Baseline.






Solution





\[\max_X \log(\lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau} - \psi X) + \beta \log(\lambda_2 wz X^\delta)^{1-\tau}\]
\[\Rightarrow \frac{\psi}{\lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau} - \psi X} = \frac{\beta (1-\tau) \delta}{\chi}\]
\[\Leftrightarrow X = \frac{1}{\psi} \times \frac{\beta (1-\tau) \delta}{1 + \beta(1-\tau) \delta} \lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau}\]
\[\Rightarrow \text{compared to } X = \frac{1}{\psi} \frac{\beta \delta}{1+\beta \delta} \Omega\]
So taxation also distorts investment in unconstrained. This could offset distortion from incomplete markets, but depends on parameters \((\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \tau)\).

text:
Part (a)
Use population moments with panel data on income to show that this income process is identified. Hint: in addition to the usual covariances, calculate \(\mathbb{V}(y_{it+1})\) and \(\mathbb{V}(y_{it+2})\) in terms of \(p_{it}\), \(\xi_{it}\), and the shocks that are realized at \(t+1\) and \(t+2\).






Solution





\[\mathbb{V}(y_{it}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathbb{V}(y_{it+1}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + \sigma_\eta^2 + \rho^2\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \sigma_\varepsilon^2\]
\[\mathbb{V}(y_{it+2}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + 2\sigma_\eta^2 + \rho^4\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + (1+\rho^2)\sigma_\varepsilon^2\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + \rho\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = C_1\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + \rho^2\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = C_2\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+3}) = \mathbb{V}(p_{it}) + \rho^3\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = C_3\]
\[\rho = \frac{C_3 - C_2}{C_2 - C_1} \quad \left(= \frac{\rho^3 - \rho^2}{\rho^2 - \rho}\right)\]
\[\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \frac{C_2 - C_1}{\rho^2 - \rho}\]
\[\mathbb{V}(p_{it}) = C_1 - \rho\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) \quad \text{or } \mathbb{V}(y_{it}) - \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
Now: Define \(B_1 = \mathbb{V}(y_{it+2}) - \mathbb{V}(y_{it+1}) - (\rho^4 - \rho^2)\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \sigma_\eta^2 + \rho^2\sigma_\varepsilon^2\)
\[B_2 = \mathbb{V}(y_{it+1}) - \rho^2\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \sigma_\eta^2 + \sigma_\varepsilon^2\]
So \(\sigma_\varepsilon^2 = \frac{(B_2 - B_1)}{1 - \rho^2}\)
and \(\sigma_\eta^2 = B_1 - \rho^2\sigma_\varepsilon^2\).

By definition, the consumption equivalent \(\bar{c}(y)\) satisfies: \[ \mathcal{V}(\bar{c}(y)) = V(0,y) \]
Substituting the formula for \(\mathcal{V}\): \[ \frac{1-\beta^{T}}{1-\beta}u(\bar{c}(y)) = V(0,y) \]
For CRRA utility, \(u(c) = \frac{c^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma}\), so: \[ \frac{1-\beta^{T}}{1-\beta} \cdot \frac{\bar{c}(y)^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma} = V(0,y) \]
Solving for \(\bar{c}(y)\): \[ \bar{c}(y)^{1-\sigma} = V(0,y) \cdot \frac{(1-\sigma)(1-\beta)}{1-\beta^{T}} \]

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Overview


Last time: The Becker-Tomes model showed how ability transmits across generations
Today: What are the skills that drive inequality?
Three main points:

Measurable cognitive and noncognitive skills explain life-cycle differences
We can estimate the technology of skill formation (and skills are malleable early in life)
Latent factor models are essential tools for dealing with measurement error

Key papers: J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006), Cunha and Heckman (2007), Cunha and Heckman (2008)

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The Importance of Skills


Standard human capital theory: education → wages
But which skills drive labor market outcomes?
Two broad categories emerge:

Cognitive skills: IQ, achievement tests, reasoning
Noncognitive skills: personality, motivation, self-control

Question: Do both types matter for economic outcomes?

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: What Do We Mean by Noncognitive Skills?
text:
What Do We Mean by Noncognitive Skills?
Examples from psychology literature:


Locus of control: belief about control over life outcomes
Self-esteem: confidence in one’s abilities
Time preference: ability to delay gratification
Conscientiousness: persistence, organization
Emotional stability: managing stress and emotions



These are often harder to measure than cognitive ability, but may be equally important.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: Evidence from Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006)
text:
Evidence from Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006)
Key empirical findings using NLSY79 data:


Both cognitive and noncognitive factors significantly affect:

Wages
Schooling attainment
Risky behaviors: smoking, crime, teen pregnancy (large!)

For many outcomes, noncognitive skills matter more than cognitive
The effects persist over the entire life cycle

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Measuring Skills: The Challenge
How do we measure cognitive and noncognitive ability?


Cognitive: ASVAB battery (Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery)

Arithmetic reasoning, word knowledge, paragraph comprehension, etc.

Noncognitive: Psychological scales

Rotter Locus of Control Scale
Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale

Problem: Measurement error!

Tests are noisy proxies for true underlying ability
Cannot simply use test scores as if they were true ability

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: Wages by Schooling and Cognitive Factor
text:
Wages by Schooling and Cognitive Factor
From J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006):


Higher cognitive ability → higher wages at all schooling levels
But the gradient is steeper for college graduates
This suggests complementarity between skills and education
Cognitive skills have bigger payoffs with more schooling

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: Wages by Schooling and Noncognitive Factor
text:
Wages by Schooling and Noncognitive Factor
From J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006):


Noncognitive skills also predict wages
The pattern is similar: higher noncognitive ability → higher wages
Effects are large and persistent
For some outcomes (e.g., crime), noncognitive effects dominate cognitive

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Educational Attainment and Skills


Both cognitive and noncognitive skills predict years of schooling
Noncognitive skills are particularly important for college completion

Requires persistence, motivation, delayed gratification
Not just ability to do the work
Also willingness to persist, study habits, etc.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Skills Are Produced
From the Becker-Tomes model, we had: \[ H_{t+1} = f(X_t, z_t) \]


But what is the technology \(f(\cdot)\)?
How do cognitive and noncognitive skills interact?
Are there critical periods for investment?
Can we compensate for early disadvantage with late investment?

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: The CES Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The CES Technology of Skill Formation
From Cunha and Heckman (2007), the technology takes the form:
\[
\theta_{k,t+1} = \left[\gamma_{1k}I_{k,t}^{\phi_k} + \gamma_{2k}\theta_{k,t}^{\phi_k}\right]^{1/\phi_k}
\]
where:


\(\theta_{k,t}\) is skill \(k\) (cognitive or noncognitive) at age \(t\)
\(I_{k,t}\) is investment in skill \(k\) at age \(t\)
\(\phi_k\) governs substitutability between early and late investments
This is a self-productive technology: skills today produce skills tomorrow

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Key Parameters: Elasticity of Substitution
The elasticity of substitution is: \[ \sigma_k = \frac{1}{1-\phi_k} \]


If \(\sigma_k\in[1,\infty)\): early and late investments are substitutes

Can compensate for poor early environment with later remediation

If \(\sigma_k\in(0,1)\): early and late investments are complements

Early investment is crucial; hard to compensate later

Empirical question: What are \(\sigma_{\text{cog}}\) and \(\sigma_{\text{noncog}}\)?

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Self-Productivity and Dynamic Complementarity
Two key properties:


Self-productivity: \(\frac{\partial \theta_{k,t+1}}{\partial \theta_{k,t}} > 0\)

Skills beget skills
Early advantage compounds over time

Dynamic complementarity: \(\frac{\partial^2 \theta_{k,t+1}}{\partial I_{k,t} \partial \theta_{k,t}} > 0\)

Early skills make later investments more productive
This creates multiplier effects




These properties have profound implications for policy timing.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Critical and Sensitive Periods
From Cunha and Heckman (2007):


Critical period: A time when \(\phi_k \leq 0\) (pure complements)

Investment must happen then; very hard to compensate later

Sensitive period: A time when \(\phi_k\in(0,1]\)

Investment is especially productive, but some later compensation possible

Evidence: Early childhood is a sensitive period for both skill types
But noncognitive skills remain more malleable into adolescence

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The Importance of Early Investment
A review of evidence in Cunha and Heckman (2007):


For cognitive skills: \(\sigma_{\text{cog}}\) is low in early childhood

Early investments are crucial
Difficult to compensate for early deprivation

For noncognitive skills: \(\sigma_{\text{noncog}}\) is somewhat higher

More room for remediation in adolescence
But still important to invest early




Policy implication: Early childhood interventions may have the highest returns.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Cross-Productivity of Skills
Another important feature from Cunha and Heckman (2008):
\[
\frac{\partial \theta_{C,t+1}}{\partial \theta_{N,t}} > 0, \quad \frac{\partial \theta_{N,t+1}}{\partial \theta_{C,t}} > 0
\]


Cognitive skills help produce noncognitive skills (and vice versa)
This creates synergies across skill dimensions
Holistic interventions may be more effective than targeted ones

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The Measurement Problem
Fundamental challenge:


We want to study the effect of true skills \(\theta\) on outcomes \(Y\)
But we only observe noisy measures \(M\) of skills
If we use \(M\) instead of \(\theta\):

Attenuation bias: underestimate true effects
Omitted variable bias: if measures are imperfect proxies

Classical measurement error: \(M = \theta + \varepsilon\)

Bias toward zero: \(\text{plim}\,\hat{\beta} = \beta \frac{\text{Var}(\theta)}{\text{Var}(\theta) + \text{Var}(\varepsilon)}\)

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The Latent Factor Approach
Example from J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006):


Assume there are \(K\) latent factors \(\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_K)\)
We observe \(J\) measurements \(M = (M_1, \ldots, M_J)\)
Each measurement loads on the factors: \[ M_j = \mu_j + \sum_{k=1}^K \alpha_{jk}\theta_k + \varepsilon_j \]
Use multiple measures to identify the factors
Correct for measurement error in estimating effects on outcomes

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Factor Model Structure
The system has three components:
Measurement equations: \[ M_j = \mu_j + \alpha_{j1}\theta_1 + \alpha_{j2}\theta_2 + \varepsilon_j, \quad j = 1, \ldots, J \]
Outcome equations: \[ Y = X\beta + \gamma_1\theta_1 + \gamma_2\theta_2 + u \]
Choice equations: \[ S = \mathbb{1}[Z\delta + \lambda_1\theta_1 + \lambda_2\theta_2 + v > 0] \]
where \(\theta_1, \theta_2\) are latent factors (e.g., cognitive and noncognitive ability).

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Identification Strategy
How do we identify this model?


Normalizations: Set scale of factors

E.g., \(\alpha_{11} = 1\), \(\alpha_{22} = 1\)

Exclusion restrictions: Some measurements don’t load on all factors

Cognitive tests only load on \(\theta_1\)
Personality scales only load on \(\theta_2\)

Multiple measurements: Need \(J \geq 2K + 1\) typically
Covariance structure: Factor model implies testable restrictions

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
section: What the Factor Model Buys Us
text:
What the Factor Model Buys Us


Correct inference about effects of skills on outcomes

No attenuation bias from measurement error

Decomposition of outcomes into skill components

How much is due to cognitive vs. noncognitive?

Predicted factors for each individual

Can use in subsequent analysis

Tests of model assumptions

Overidentification restrictions

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Example: NLSY79 Data
J. Heckman, Stixrud, and Urzua (2006) use:

Cognitive measurements:

ASVAB: Arithmetic reasoning, word knowledge, paragraph comprehension, math knowledge, coding speed

Noncognitive measurements:

Rotter Locus of Control Scale, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale



With two factors and multiple measures, the model is overidentified and can be tested.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Estimating the Factor Distribution
Key methodological point from Cunha and Heckman (2007):


Traditional factor analysis assumes normal factors
But factors may be non-normal in reality
Solution: Use mixture of normals \[ f(\theta_k) = \sum_{j=1}^{J_k} p_{kj} \phi(\theta_k | \mu_{kj}, \sigma_{kj}^2) \]
This is flexible and nests normality as a special case
Allows for skewness, multimodality, etc.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Separating Heterogeneity from Uncertainty
Another interesting use of factor models (from the Cunha and Heckman (2007)):


Observed wage variance has two sources:

Heterogeneity: differences in \(\theta\) known to agent at age 17
Uncertainty: shocks \(\varepsilon\) unknown at age 17

Factor model + choice data lets us separate these
How? If \(\theta \in I\) (agent’s info set), it affects choices
If \(\varepsilon \notin I\), it doesn’t affect choices
By using choice data, we learn what agents knew when

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Findings on Predictability
From Cunha and Heckman (2007):


About 80% of lifetime earnings variance is predictable at age 17
Only 20% is due to genuine uncertainty (“luck”)
Most inequality is due to heterogeneity in skills
This heterogeneity is measurable using factor methods



Implication: Early interventions can have large effects because most variance is in place early.

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Bringing It Together
What have we learned?


Both cognitive and noncognitive skills matter enormously
Noncognitive skills are often more important than we thought
Skills have a production technology with:

Self-productivity
Dynamic complementarity
Low substitutability early in life

Measurement error is severe; factor models are essential
Most earnings inequality is heterogeneity (not luck)

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Policy Implications


Invest early: Critical and sensitive periods suggest high returns to early childhood
Holistic interventions: Target both cognitive and noncognitive skills
Compensatory programs: May need to be very early due to low substitutability
Measurement matters:

Policy evaluations need to account for measurement error
Standard approaches may severely understate program effects

Targeting: Focus on children from disadvantaged backgrounds

They face both low \(\theta\) and low \(I\)
Dynamic complementarity means early intervention is most effective for them
No equity-efficiency trade-off

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
The Perry Preschool Program
A famous example: J. J. Heckman et al. (2010)


High-quality preschool for disadvantaged 3-4 year olds
Large, persistent effects on:

Educational attainment
Earnings
Crime reduction

Effects work through both cognitive and noncognitive channels
But noncognitive effects persist while cognitive fade
Illustrates importance of early, comprehensive intervention

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Remaining Questions


Which noncognitive skills are most malleable?
How do parental investments respond to child skills?

Reinforcing or compensating?

Can we remediate in adolescence?

Evidence suggests yes for noncognitive, harder for cognitive

What policies are most cost-effective?
How do skills interact with institutions (schools, labor markets)?

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Next Steps


Next lectures will explore:

Quantitative models of intergenerational mobility
Parenting and investments
Policy evaluation: ECE, safety net, etc.

We’ll use the framework developed today as a foundation
Recurring theme: Dynamic complementarity makes timing crucial

title: Skills, Inequality, and the Technology of Skill Formation
text:
Key Takeaways


Skills are multidimensional: cognitive and noncognitive both matter
Skills are produced according to a technology with important properties
Early life is a critical period due to low substitutability
Measurement error is a first-order problem; factor models solve it
Most inequality is heterogeneity, not luck
Policy: Invest early, invest holistically, target disadvantaged

text:
Problem 3: Income Process with Measurement Error
Consider the income process:
\[y_{it} = \alpha_i + \xi_{it} + \varepsilon_{it} + \theta \varepsilon_{i,t-1}\]
where \(\xi_{it} = \rho \xi_{it-1} + \eta_{it}\), and \((\eta_{it}, \varepsilon_{it})\) are iid with \(\mathbb{V}[\alpha_i] = \sigma_\alpha^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\varepsilon_{it}] = \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\), \(\mathbb{V}[\eta_{it}] = \sigma_\eta^2\).
Use population moments to identify the parameters of the income process.






Solution





Variance of income:
\[\mathbb{V}[y_{it}] = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + (1+\theta^2) \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+1}) = C_1 = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) + \theta \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+2}) = C_2 = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\mathcal{C}(y_{it}, y_{it+s}) = C_s = \sigma_\alpha^2 + \rho^s \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) \quad \forall \, s > 1\]
Identification:
\[\rho = \frac{C_4 - C_3}{C_3 - C_2} = \frac{\rho^4 - \rho^3}{\rho^3 - \rho^2} \checkmark\]
\[\mathbb{V}(\xi_{it}) = \frac{C_3 - C_2}{\rho^3 - \rho^2}, \quad \sigma_\alpha^2 = C_2 - \rho^2 \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})\]
\[\frac{(1+\theta^2)}{\theta} = \frac{\mathbb{V}(y_{it}) - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}{C_1 - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \rho \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}\]
\(\Rightarrow\) \(\theta\) is solution to quadratic.
\[\Rightarrow \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 = \frac{\mathbb{V}(y_{it}) - \sigma_\alpha^2 - \mathbb{V}(\xi_{it})}{(1+\theta^2)}\]
Done.

title: Practice Exercises
section: Problem 4: One-Period Model with Lognormal Income
text:
Problem 4: One-Period Model with Lognormal Income
Consider the following one period model:
\[C_i = Y_i = \exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)\]
where \(\varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2)\), \(\alpha_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2)\). Suppose that \(\alpha_i\) is known to each individual and \(\varepsilon_i\) is income risk. Assume log utility s.t. \(V(\alpha_i) = \mathbb{E}[\log(C_i) | \alpha_i]\).

Part (a)
Show that \(V(\alpha_i) = \alpha_i\).






Solution





\[V(\alpha_i) = \mathbb{E}[\log(C_i) | \alpha_i] = \mathbb{E}[\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i | \alpha_i] = \alpha_i\]





Part (b)
Suppose a planner solves:
\[\max_{\{C_i\}_{i\in[0,1]}} \int \log(C_i) di \quad \text{s.t.} \quad \int C_i di = \int \exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)di\]
Show that the solution is
\[C_i^* = C^* = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\]
Hint: if \(Z \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2)\), \(\mathbb{E}[\exp(Z)] = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2)\).






Solution





Since \(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2 + \sigma_{\varepsilon}^2)\), \(\int\exp(\alpha_{i}+\varepsilon_{i})di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\).
Planner’s FOC: \(\frac{1}{C_i} = \lambda \quad \forall \, i\)
where \(\lambda\) is multiplier on resource constraint. Hence \(C_i = C^* \quad \forall \, i\).
Plugging into resource constraint gives
\[C^* = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2))\]





Part (c)
Show that the certainty equivalent \(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)\) that delivers \(V(\alpha_i)\) is \(\overline{C}(\alpha_i) = \exp(\alpha_i)\).






Solution





\(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)\) solves
\[\log(\overline{C}(\alpha_i)) = V(\alpha_i) = \alpha_i\]
\[\Rightarrow \overline{C}(\alpha_i) = \exp(\alpha_i)\]





Part (d)
Show that \(\overline{C} = \int \overline{C}(\alpha_{i})di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_{\alpha})\)






Note





Since \(\alpha_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_\alpha^2)\),
\[\overline{C} = \int \overline{C}(\alpha_i) di = \exp(\mu + \frac{1}{2}\sigma_\alpha^2)\]





Part (e)
Show that the planner’s objective is \(\mu\) in the baseline and \(\mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2)\) at the optimum.






Solution





Baseline: \(W = \int \log(C_i) = \int \log(\exp(\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i)) di = \mathbb{E}[\alpha_i + \varepsilon_i] = \mu\)
\[W^* = \log(C^*) = \mu + \frac{1}{2}(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 + \sigma_\alpha^2)\]





Part (f)
Decompose \(W^* - W\) into two components:

\(W^* - \log(\overline{C})\)
\(\log(\overline{C}) - W\)

What is (1)? What is (2)? Which term represents the gains from insurance?






Solution






\(W^* - \log(\overline{C}) = \frac{1}{2}\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2 \leftarrow\) Insurance
\(\log(\overline{C}) - W = \frac{1}{2}\sigma_\alpha^2 \leftarrow\) Redistribution






Part (g)
Make sense! \(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\) is variance component in \(y_{it}\) coming from risk, \(\sigma_\alpha^2\) is the component coming from ex-ante inequality.






Interpretation





\(\sigma_{\varepsilon}^2\) measures the variance in income coming from idiosyncratic risk that individuals face. Insurance eliminates this uncertainty.
\(\sigma_\alpha^2\) measures the variance in income coming from permanent differences across individuals (ex-ante inequality). Redistribution addresses this component.

text:
Problem 5: Two-Period Becker-Tomes Model
Consider the 2-period Becker-Tomes model:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2, X, A} U(C_1) + \beta U(C_2)\]
\[\text{s.t.} \quad C_1 + \psi X + A / (1+r) \leq \Omega + T / (1+r)\]
\[C_2 = A + wz X^\delta - T, \quad A \geq 0\]
where \(T\) is a lump-sum tax paid by generation 2 to generation 1.

Part (a)
Show that if a household is not constrained, the value of \(T\) does not affect any allocations of \(C_1, C_2, X\) at the optimum. (Hint: try combining budget constraints).






Solution





If \(A > 0\) at the optimum, can combine to get:
\[C_1 + C_2/(1+r) \leq \Omega + wz X^\delta/(1+r) \quad (*)\]
s.t. household solves:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2} U(C_1) + \beta U(C_2) \quad \text{s.t.} \quad (*)\]
Hence \(T\) does not feature.





Part (b)
Show that for constrained households:
\[U'(C_1) = \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{(1+r)} U'(C_2) \quad \text{and} \quad (1+r) \leq \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\]






Solution





When \(A = 0\), solve:
\[\max_{C_1, C_2} U(\Omega + T/(1+r) - \psi X) + \beta U(wz X^\delta - T)\]
get
\[U'(\Omega + T/(1+r) - \psi X) = \beta \delta wz X^{\delta-1} U'(wz X^\delta - T)\]
\[\Leftrightarrow U'(C_1) \psi = \beta \delta wz^{\delta-1} U'(wz X^\delta - T)\]
Note that the marginal return (in assets) is
\[-\frac{1}{1+r} U'(C_1) + \beta U'(C_2) \leq 0 \quad \Leftrightarrow (1+r) \leq \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\]
(if \(> 0\), then household should optimally increase \(A\) above 0).





Part (c)
Consider a marginal increase in \(T\). What happens to the welfare of constrained vs unconstrained households?






Solution





If \(T \nearrow\) marginally, change in welfare is
\[u'(C_1) \frac{1}{(1+r)} - \beta u'(C_2) > 0\]
for constrained households, where inequality follows from (b).
Since allocations of constrained households are unaffected by \(T\) \(\Rightarrow\) no welfare effect.
Note: not clear if welfare of children \(\nearrow\) in this intervention.

section: Problem 6: Two-Period Model with Progressive Taxation
text:
Problem 6: Two-Period Model with Progressive Taxation
For the same 2-period model, suppose budget constraints are now:
\[C_1 + A/(1+r) + \psi X \leq \lambda_{1} \Omega^{1-\tau}\]
\[C_2 = A + \lambda_2 (wz X^\delta)^{1-\tau}, \quad A \geq 0\]
where \(\lambda_1\) and \(\lambda_2\) are chosen to balance budget in each period.

Part (a)
Write the FOC for unconstrained households.






Solution





For unconstrained:
\[(1+r) = \frac{\lambda_2 (1-\tau) \delta(w z) X^{\delta(1-\tau)-1}}{\psi}\]





Part (b)
Recall that the planner would set, if possible, \((1+r) = \frac{wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\) in each household \(i\). Can the equilibrium with taxation be efficient?






Solution





Comparing to the condition \((1+r) = \frac{\delta wz X^{\delta-1}}{\psi}\),
taxation distorts the optimal allocation of financials \(\Rightarrow\) human capital \(\Rightarrow\) not efficient.





Part (c)
Explain, in words, the efficiency cost of progressive taxation in this model. (Hint: compare the household’s FOC to the planner’s).






Solution





Redistribution reduces the incentives for parents to invest. \(\Rightarrow\) An equity-efficiency tradeoff.





Part (d)
Assuming log utility, solve for \(X\) when households are constrained. Comment on solution relative to Baseline.






Solution





\[\max_X \log(\lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau} - \psi X) + \beta \log(\lambda_2 wz X^\delta)^{1-\tau}\]
\[\Rightarrow \frac{\psi}{\lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau} - \psi X} = \frac{\beta (1-\tau) \delta}{\chi}\]
\[\Leftrightarrow X = \frac{1}{\psi} \times \frac{\beta (1-\tau) \delta}{1 + \beta(1-\tau) \delta} \lambda_1 \Omega^{1-\tau}\]
\[\Rightarrow \text{compared to } X = \frac{1}{\psi} \frac{\beta \delta}{1+\beta \delta} \Omega\]
So taxation also distorts investment in unconstrained. This could offset distortion from incomplete markets, but depends on parameters \((\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \tau)\).

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Overview


We’ve studied theoretical models of human capital formation and mobility
Today: empirical evidence on how policy affects skill formation
Focus: social safety net programs
Key questions:

Do income transfers affect child development?
What are the long-run effects on education and earnings?
How do these findings connect to our theoretical models?

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
What is the EITC?


Refundable tax credit for low-income working families
Phases in with earnings, plateaus, then phases out
For families with children, substantial benefits (max ~$7,000)
Key features:

Conditional on working (labor supply incentive)
Varies with number of children
Expanded significantly in 1993

A few ways to use this variation

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
EITC Schedule


Three regions:

Phase-in: credit increases with earnings
Plateau: credit remains constant
Phase-out: credit decreases with earnings

Creates variation in income while holding work incentives roughly constant

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Research Question


Does family income causally affect child achievement?
Previous research showed correlations, but hard to separate:

Direct income effect
Selection (parents with higher income have other advantages)

Innovation: use EITC expansions as exogenous income shocks
Focus on test scores as outcomes

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Identification Strategy


Compare children in families eligible for large vs small EITC increases
Key variation: 1993 EITC expansion differentially affected families by initial earnings level
Use predicted income growth conditional on earnings as an instrument for actual income growth
To use this variation, must also control for initial earnings

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Main Results
From (Dahl and Lochner 2012):


Effect size: $1,000 increase in income → 6% of standard deviation increase in test scores
Effects concentrated in math and reading
Larger effects for:

Younger children
More disadvantaged families

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Connecting to Theory
These findings validate and extend our models:


Credit constraints bind: low-income families would invest more if they could
Self-productivity: early investments have compounding returns
Dynamic complementarity: nutrition, health, cognitive stimulation interact
Multiple skills: cognitive and non-cognitive both affected
Intergenerational transmission: improved child outcomes → improved parenting → next generation



Where do the models need refinement?


More explicit modeling of multiple input types
Better understanding of production function non-linearities
Behavioral aspects (information, salience, planning)

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Long-Run Effects of EITC
(Bastian and Michelmore 2018) ask: what are the lifetime impacts of EITC exposure?


Follow children exposed to EITC expansions into adulthood
Outcomes:

Educational attainment
Employment
Earnings

Key insight: childhood income may have persistent effects

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Identification Strategy


Exploit state-level EITC programs (additional to federal)
Timing: states adopted at different times
Compare children in same state, different birth cohorts
State, year, family size \(\rightarrow\) different max credit

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Main Findings


$1,000 increase in EITC exposure (age 13-18) leads to:

1.3 percentage point increase in high school completion
Higher college attendance
2% increase in earnings in mid-20s

The EITC is a work incentive and had an effect on maternal labor supply

Changes in money and time with children

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Mechanisms
What drives these long-run effects?


Direct channel: more resources → better inputs (nutrition, healthcare, learning materials)
Indirect channels:

Reduced parental stress
Better neighborhoods (if families move)
More stable home environment

Complementarity with early investments (dynamic complementarity from Cunha-Heckman)

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
The Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend


Annual cash transfer to all Alaska residents
Funded by oil revenues
Varies annually (~$1,000-$2,000 per person)
Key features:

Universal (no income targeting)
Unconditional (no work requirement)
Substantial for families with children

Different policy design than EITC

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Research Question
Do cash transfers in the first year of life affect long-run child outcomes?


Focus: transfer received (or not) right after birth
Compare children born just before vs just after January 1
Innovation: use universe of administrative tax data
Follow children into adulthood (measure earnings in 20s)
Also examine intermediate outcomes (test scores, graduation)

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Identification


Exploit year-to-year variation in dividend amounts
Compare children born in high-dividend vs low-dividend years
Within-family analysis: siblings born in different years
Assumption: dividend amount uncorrelated with other determinants of child outcomes



Potential concerns?


Oil price shocks affect local economy
Response: control for local economic conditions, use within-family variation
Fertility responses
Response: show no evidence of selection into birth timing

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Main Results
Children who received ~$1,300 transfer in first year show:


Long-run earnings: 1-2% higher at age 20-25

Larger effects for males (3-4%)
Concentrated among low-income families

Intermediate outcomes:

Higher math and reading test scores
Increased high school graduation rates

Effects emerge early and persist



Return on investment: $1,300 transfer yields increased lifetime earnings far exceeding cost

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Comparing EITC and PFD
What do we learn from comparing these programs?


EITC: conditional on work, targeted to low-income
PFD: unconditional, universal
Both show positive effects on children
Suggests income effect is important, not just selection or work requirements
Timing matters: largest effects for transfers early in life

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
The Food Stamp Program


In-kind transfer program (now called SNAP)
Provides food benefits to low-income households
Rolled out county-by-county between 1961-1975
Research opportunity: quasi-experimental variation in timing of access

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net

Compare cohorts born just before vs just after Food Stamps arrived
Within-county variation in exposure by birth year
Link historical rollout data to modern outcomes
Long-run outcomes: health, education, economic self-sufficiency in adulthood

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Main Findings
Childhood access to Food Stamps led to:


Health: reduced metabolic syndrome, obesity in adulthood
Education: increased high school completion
Economic: higher earnings, less likely to receive government assistance
Intergenerational: children of treated individuals have better outcomes
Effects larger for:

More disadvantaged families
Exposure during early childhood and in utero




Interpretation: nutrition and food security in childhood have lifelong consequences

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Return on Investment


Authors calculate cost-benefit ratio
Benefits from:

Higher earnings (increased tax revenue)
Better health (lower medical costs)
Less transfer receipt (lower government spending)

Find ROI of approximately 56 cents per dollar spent
Interpretation: Food Stamps are an investment not just consumption

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
The Family Nurse Partnership
(Carneiro et al. 2021) study a different type of intervention:


Home visiting program for first-time disadvantaged mothers
Intensive: regular visits from pregnancy through age 2
Focus on:

Prenatal health
Parenting skills
Life planning

Randomized controlled trial in UK

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Multifaceted Intervention


Not just income, but also:

Information (about child development, health)
Skills (parenting techniques)
Support (reducing stress, connecting to services)

Question: can we separate income from other channels?

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Main Results


Child anthropometrics (2 years post-intervention):

Height-for-age Z-score increases by 0.22σ
Stunting reduced by 8%, extreme stunting by 15%
Effects sustained at 4 years

Child health:

18% reduction in diarrhea episodes
Increased vaccination and deworming rates

Mother’s labor supply:

21% increase in earnings at 2 years, sustained at 4 years
Increased livestock ownership (key for protein-rich diets)

Cognition

Effect on communication, but fade-out

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Interpreting Through Our Models


Becker-Tomes: intervention relaxes budget constraints AND provides information
Evidence of binding credit constraints for low-income families
Technology of skill formation (Cunha-Heckman):

Early investments matter (impacts on gestation, early nutrition)
Multiple inputs: cash enables protein-rich foods, better practices
Dynamic complementarity: early health + continued investment

Unique insight: Cash transfers enable productive investments (livestock) that generate sustained income

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
What Have We Learned?


Income matters: Causal evidence from EITC, PFD, Food Stamps
Timing is critical: Largest effects for early childhood exposure
Long-run effects: Childhood resources affect adult outcomes
Multiple channels: Income, information, parenting, health all matter
Intergenerational: Effects potentially transmit to next generation



Policy implication: Safety net programs are investments in human capital, not just transfers

Direct purchases (food, books, healthcare)
Parental time allocation
Stress reduction
Neighborhood quality

section: Tax Benefits and the Birthday Lottery
text:
Tax Benefits and the Birthday Lottery
(Barr, Eggleston, and Smith 2022) exploit a natural experiment: the January 1 birthdate cutoff


U.S. child tax benefits determined by December 31 cutoff
Child born December 31 → family gets full tax year benefits
Child born January 1 → family waits a year for benefits
Natural randomization: due date doesn’t predict birth date precisely
Average difference: ~$1,300 for low-income families (~10% of annual income)

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Identification Strategy


Key assumption: children born Dec 31 vs Jan 1 are similar except for transfer timing
Potential threats:

C-sections scheduled to manipulate birth date?
Response: show no bunching around January 1
Different demographics around cutoff?
Response: show balance on observables

Window: focus on births within days of cutoff

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Mechanisms and Timing
Why do transfers in infancy matter?


Critical period: first year of life is developmentally important

Brain development
Nutrition and health
Parent-child bonding

Families may be especially credit-constrained after birth
Small amounts can have large effects if spent on high-return investments

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Comparing Policy Designs
What do we learn from comparing EITC and tax benefit studies?


EITC: conditional on work, recurrent, predictable
Tax benefits: unconditional, one-time, unpredictable
Both show positive effects on children
Suggests:

Income effect is important, not just work incentives
Even one-time transfers can have lasting effects
Timing matters: transfers when children are very young may be especially valuable

The Child Development Grant Programme (CDGP)
(Carneiro et al. 2021) study a multifaceted intervention in Northern Nigeria:


Information provision to mothers and fathers on pregnancy and infant feeding practices
Cash transfers to mothers: $22/month (85% of women’s earnings)
Transfers begin during pregnancy, continue until child is 24 months
Implemented at village level, targeted to pregnant women
Randomized controlled trial with 3,688 pregnant women at baseline

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Why This Context Matters


Northern Nigeria: extreme poverty (70% below $1.90/day)
High stunting rates (67% of children under 5)
Infant mortality: 90 per 1,000 births
Low knowledge of child nutrition practices
Women retain control over resources they bring into household
Agricultural lean season creates food insecurity

title: Connecting Theory with Evidence: The Safety Net
text:
Long-Run Impacts and Mechanisms


Key mechanisms:

Increased parental knowledge and improved practices (breastfeeding, antenatal care)
Women invest transfers in livestock assets → protein-rich foods for children
Labor supply increases (no reduction despite transfers)
Food security improves, especially during lean season

Sustained effects: impacts persist 2 years after transfers end
Return on investment: Internal rate of return 5-20% depending on assumptions

text:
A Brief Recap


We found that for unconstrained households, optimal investments are not affected by economic resources.

Finding effects of resources / interventions, a sign of constraints \(\Rightarrow\) welfare and efficiency gains

No!! e.g. \(z_{t-1}\rightarrow \Omega\) and \(z_{t}\rightarrow H_{t+1}\)
